componenttext: Great. And then the second question, maybe talk a little bit about what you're seeing in Brazil, both from your business and from Jarden's business and kind of the outlook expected this year.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our Brazilian business has struggled, our Tools business in Brazil, in particular, and it's by far the biggest components of the new Newell Brands. You're  talking about a businesses that's over $100 million there. And it's been a struggle. In partic
componenttext: Yes, our Brazilian business has struggled, our Tools business in Brazil, in particular, and it's by far the biggest components of the new Newell Brands. You're  talking about a businesses that's over $100 million there. And it's been a struggle. In particular, given currency movements to maintain margins, so we priced significantly in Brazil and have lost volume momentum there. This is an ongoing struggle, it's all built into our guidance, but I think this is going to be a tough year for our Tools business in Brazil. We've had light challenges on the Jarden side of our business. That said, both companies have done well in Latin America in the first quarter despite -- in the case of legacy Newell, the absence of Venezuela and the numbers and the challenges in Brazil. Newell's core growth in Brazil was actually down materially in the first quarter. So despite that, delivered 5.5% growth and Jarden had some similar challenges there. I will say, within the Jarden numbers, one of the standout performances in the first quarter was JCS, so despite having a footprint that intersects with those dynamics that I was describing in Brazil, the business, in aggregate, did quite well.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So post-close, as you guys been able to take closer look at the Jarden business the last few weeks here, any kind of positive or negative surprises on your side as you look at it, what kind of shape you think the portfolio is in from the core sales growth
componenttext: So post-close, as you guys been able to take closer look at the Jarden business the last few weeks here, any kind of positive or negative surprises on your side as you look at it, what kind of shape you think the portfolio is in from the core sales growth standpoint and as you look at innovation pipeline. And also then on the synergy front, any updated thoughts on if you might integrate these companies from a supply chain or manufacturing standpoint more than you were original assuming in the synergies you've laid out? And if you do, what type of synergy level that could unlock?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we've been, obviously, as you can imagine, we've been engaged, Bill and Mark, in particular, Rez, Rick, really engaged in getting up to speed on the Jarden businesses over the last number of months to the degree that we could and since the 15th,
componenttext: Sure. So we've been, obviously, as you can imagine, we've been engaged, Bill and Mark, in particular, Rez, Rick, really engaged in getting up to speed on the Jarden businesses over the last number of months to the degree that we could and since the 15th, with much greater depth. And the teams -- in fact, all the teams from across Newell and legacy Newell and legacy Jarden are together next week for the week and we're really going to dive on each other's businesses so we're going to share, we're going to learn, we're going to connect, we're going to get into this and a lot greater detail as we try to build out one integrated company leadership team. So that's very exciting it will be fun on the social side, but more importantly, we'll get into the details of the business. Jarden have good momentum. As I mentioned JCS had good growth in the first quarter, on great growth year-ago period, double-digit growth a year ago and very good growth in the first quarter on top of that. Yankee, again, double-digit growth a year-ago period. Great growth in the first quarter on top of that. So we've got some decent momentum in some of the most important assets that are in the Jarden portfolio and as you can tell from our numbers, you got similar momentum in our most strategically critical businesses like writing. So we feel terrific. We're right where we expected to be in the combination and we're excited by the possibilities. Now we're going go through the work over the summer of establishing portfolio priorities just like we did when we got to Newell Rubbermaid and obviously, JCS and Yankee will be priority businesses for us going forward with writing and with food and beverage and likely suspects that you're familiar with from the former Newell businesses. But we'll go through that rigorous process of establishing portfolio of priorities through the summer. Now we've got the board meeting in a couple of weeks where we'll expose our approach to the board. And by the August board meeting, we'll be ready to lock in our portfolio, prioritization choices in that you should expect resources to align to those priorities and we'll invest heavily on the businesses with the greatest potential, the greatest right to win and we'll add the other businesses to win differently, to win in a different ways than by leveraging the big investments in brand development and design and an innovation that we'll place in our priority business. So you should expect that logic that drove the choices within Newell Rubbermaid to drive the choices in the combined Newell Brands. Now that said, all businesses have to grow, all businesses have to grow ahead of the markets, growth is the engine that powers the company, and it's really critical for our teams to embrace that. Based on what I've seen, I think that's going to be a really easy thing for us to land as an integrated company. The values of the operational intensity that underpins things that we've done over the last few years are clearly in place on the Jarden businesses. So I'm quite optimistic about their not being and a cultural or social issues without getting aligned on how we intend to operate. With respect to synergies, obviously, synergy is going to flow to margin. The work on Rubbermaid, there's still left to do, the $300 million savings we hope to get roughly $300 million. Half of that will flow into investment. Where we put those investment's debts -- I'm quite agnostic about that. The fact that the savings are coming from -- that we would invest back are coming from legacy Newell Rubbermaid, doesn't mean that the spending will happen there. So we're going to make sure that our strategy yields set of outcomes are greater than some of the parts. So we're going to take money and put it on the businesses with the greatest right to win. So I feel great about where we are these really early stages. Everybody's sprinting. We're excited by the possibilities and energized by the work ahead.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And moving forward, your next question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays capital.
componenttext: And moving forward, your next question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays capital.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about the exit. I think in the release, it sounded like it could be a combination from both legacy companies. And then, what is it specific the Jarden, are those things that you think you'll  -- is it the same
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about the exit. I think in the release, it sounded like it could be a combination from both legacy companies. And then, what is it specific the Jarden, are those things that you think you'll  -- is it the same thing as sort of fix the businesses? The way that you address Western Europe or Baby in your own portfolio?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as you know, our inclination is to get into these businesses and choose to fix them rather than either sell them or exit them. In certain cases within our last 5-year history at Newell Rubbermaid, we've made the choice to exit as we did in Europe
componenttext: Yes. So as you know, our inclination is to get into these businesses and choose to fix them rather than either sell them or exit them. In certain cases within our last 5-year history at Newell Rubbermaid, we've made the choice to exit as we did in Europe with a critical enabler that the exits we took on in Europe were critical enablers that is getting the cost structure down, particularly in our distribution transportation networks. And so as you know, the profitability went from less than $10 million in Europe in 2019 to over $100 million in Europe as a result of some of those choices. Now, of course, those savings come out because of those integrated choices on exits on reprioritizing portfolio of choices. We're going to likely phase into similar dynamics within the Jarden business and while it's premature to specifically call out businesses that we would exit because our inclination is to first build fix, over the summer as we get more opportunity to connect with you, we'll bring, in China, broader light on the specifics that underpin the headline. It was important for us to lay that out for you so that you understood the core sales growth guidance and didn't misread the dynamics that are embedded within it. So we'll see how this all plays out. There certainly are some assets on the Newell Rubbermaid side that we consider exiting as well. And if we got some point where we made the choice, the first question we'd ask is, could we sell them rather than exit them. But given that it's early and we wanted to set course guidance expectations, we probably appropriate to articulate the boundaries around the product line exits that we may choose to implement.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then if I could just ask one more question on Tools. Talk about A&P being up and my recollection is that both that business and Commercial Products we kind of flirted with and committed to A&P dollars with your mix results in terms of the actua
componenttext: Great. And then if I could just ask one more question on Tools. Talk about A&P being up and my recollection is that both that business and Commercial Products we kind of flirted with and committed to A&P dollars with your mix results in terms of the actual returns. Is there anything in particular that set up advertising behind it, is it a new initiative or is it something where you have done before and seeing a positive return?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is an open question for us, particularly on Tools. On Commercial Products, we pulled back the spending to roughly 3%, 3.5% of revenue and I think that's where you should expect us to keep it unless we have some big news there that we want to punctuat
componenttext: This is an open question for us, particularly on Tools. On Commercial Products, we pulled back the spending to roughly 3%, 3.5% of revenue and I think that's where you should expect us to keep it unless we have some big news there that we want to punctuate. As you know, we've learned that doing mathematics advertising didn't work that we were better to advertise new items in the news, and that's where our advertising on Tools has been focused as we've launched new items in the back half of 2015 that have flowed into 2016. But we're going to continue to ask questions about this because particularly in the light of the broader portfolio because there's businesses like Yankee, there are businesses like the appliance business, there's some other aspects of the Jarden portfolio that we feel could benefit from increased A&P support. So as we go through the process of making the portfolio choices across the total portfolio, some of those priorities that we had placed in legacy Newell may change as we take out a broader -- we broaden our perspective on the businesses with the greatest potential. And so some of that money that might have historically been spent on Tools could very well these leads -- find their way to being spent on Yankee or on appliance launches or on any number of other businesses that have interesting things going on. So I thank you should keep an open mind as to how we go through the process over the next few weeks and months towards probably a late summer articulation of those priorities to the broader market. And you will see us reallocate resources based on them, both human capital and money.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And then, John, just housekeeping, what's the interest expense levels at the full year that we should be using?
componenttext: That's great. And then, John, just housekeeping, what's the interest expense levels at the full year that we should be using?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So overall for us, I think the -- I'll give in terms of our rate, it's a little over -- up 4.04% [indiscernible] on a pretax basis. In terms of dollars, about $400 million.
componenttext: So overall for us, I think the -- I'll give in terms of our rate, it's a little over -- up 4.04% [indiscernible] on a pretax basis. In terms of dollars, about $400 million.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Steve Powers with UBS.
componenttext: The next question comes from Steve Powers with UBS.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a great start on the Newell side. Maybe just a little more color if you could on what to expect on just over the balance of the year in terms of quarterly cadence likewise on the Dryden site, puts and takes the call out. If you could also quantify the
componenttext: So a great start on the Newell side. Maybe just a little more color if you could on what to expect on just over the balance of the year in terms of quarterly cadence likewise on the Dryden site, puts and takes the call out. If you could also quantify the amortization benefit of backing out those expenses from legacy Newell, that would help unless I missed it. And really, my broader question, and you touched upon a little bit is, just ask you if you could talk a bit more about the process by which year going to put together your plans looking out fiscal '17 and beyond. I know you're going to meet next week and get in front of the board by August. But could you just talk a little bit more about who's involved and the timing of likely decisions, the timing of communication, whether internally, externally. And really what your biggest priorities are inputting those plans together? Is it incremental cost a synergies, revenue synergies, portfolio of choices, getting the organization right? I just want to know more about how you thinking about things as you embark on solidifying a combined company strategy over the long term.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So Steve, there's 3 kind of questions there and I'll deal with the first one, which is on I think your question was focused on the Jarden business so I'll give you my perspective on both with respect to the flow of growth through the year. And then
componenttext: Right. So Steve, there's 3 kind of questions there and I'll deal with the first one, which is on I think your question was focused on the Jarden business so I'll give you my perspective on both with respect to the flow of growth through the year. And then I'll let John answer the questions on amortization, and then I'll come back on the process. So as you know, Jarden's Q1 are really -- is really a pretty light quarter with respect to its overall impact, the total trajectory of the business. The year-ago numbers, if you look at the year-ago numbers, they're bridging first quarter year ago, I think, at 4.8% organic growth; second quarter, 6%, third -- 6% or 7%, 7%. And 6% in the third quarter and about 2% in the fourth quarter. And so the year-ago comparators are tougher in the first3 quarters than they are in the balance of the year. That said, growth on the Jarden business should pick up through the year as it historically have. And as I've said, we've got good momentum and obviously, a little bit of an easier comp in Q4 than we do in the early part of the year. Q4 obviously, most important quarter for Jarden and I think we're well positioned and the teams are well positioned to now -- the activities that have to be hit excluded at the window to deliver the outcomes. Of course, where there's always a variable in the fourth quarter for their businesses, so we wont count on anything other than normal weather conditions. But I think we're in a good position to land right in the middle of the guidance range we've articulated. On the Newell side, we got terrific momentum. I think we particularly in the Writing business, where ex-Venezuela a year ago, our growth was probably around 6.5-ish percent and to nail 88 in the first quarter without the benefit of Venezuela is a sign of building momentum. We've launched all of our new items earlier in the year than we did last year. We've got interesting momentum now building on the Rubbermaid brand behind the launch of FRESHWORKS and Fasten + Go, we've got a great launch coming to the back half of the year. So the year has the potential to be the Renaissance year for the Rubbermaid brand so we're excited about that. We've got ongoing momentum in beverages. Baby put it another terrific quarter with 9% -- over 9% core growth. And Tools came in stronger quite frankly than expected. Commercial was probably a little softer than we expected. It's timing related. But in aggregate, a 5.6% growth in the first quarter is great, probably our first quarter in a long, long time and given the underlying momentum being driven by new products and strengthened investment beyond the brands, we're  encourage that, that should be able to continue. We've guided to the middle of the guidance range on Newell Rubbermaid and we'll see if things continue as they did in Q1, maybe there's some upside to that. But we'll have to see how the full year plays out, it's a little too early to get too excited although I'd much rather start the way we did than not. So in aggregate, we're feeling pretty darn good about where we're at. We -- our expectations for the Jarden performance in the first quarter were virtually right in line with them. The complexion obviously, within in any of these businesses by business how the numbers aggregate out is always a little bit different than you expect, but that's sort of the normal natural flow. Now with respect to amortization.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Steve to answer your question on the Newell side, the tick up in terms of normalized earnings associated with the normalization of the amortization intangibles. On a full year basis, it's about $38 million. If you take the 8.5 months this year assuming
componenttext: So Steve to answer your question on the Newell side, the tick up in terms of normalized earnings associated with the normalization of the amortization intangibles. On a full year basis, it's about $38 million. If you take the 8.5 months this year assuming that we're going to start it at that time period, it's about $24 million this year, and those are both pretax numbers.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on process with respect to portfolio of choices, we are together next week to come together as leadership team and the folks that will be there are the business unit leaders, the finance leaders, a number of their leadership teams, team members.
componenttext: And then on process with respect to portfolio of choices, we are together next week to come together as leadership team and the folks that will be there are the business unit leaders, the finance leaders, a number of their leadership teams, team members. And it is in part social to get to know each other, both sides of the family and also to get into the businesses. So each business will go through a business review that all of the other businesses will learn from as well as management. And then Bill and Mark and the team will do -- the teams would do a much deeper dive on the Jarden businesses towards the end of the week. That information that work, that thinking will all inform the portfolio of choice activities that we'll go through the summer. This is an analytic process. It's not subjective, so we're going to look at market mapping globally, we're going to look at we began this work, we're going to look at market in category growth rates globally, we'll look at the strength of brands by geography. We've got that research in flight already to understand where brands have leverage and the intersection of people's thinking on the businesses with the broad analytic macro view of geography, category and channel dynamics, plus brand strength will inform -- and the competitive strength will inform where we place our bets. And obviously, margins and financial attractiveness contribute to that whole bit of analysis. So there will be lots of folks inputting, there will be a few folks that are doing the [indiscernible] rigor. Through the summer, end of June, my team will get together for a week, my direct team, to talk about the results and talk about the path forward and that strategic work will be refined through July, to the August board meeting and then we'll probably come public with this of that in early September and then all of our choices with be -- for '17 we'll be informed by that piece of work. So you should expect us to we will be reallocating resources the businesses with the highest potential as part of our 2017 planning process.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll hear from John Faucher from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And next, we'll hear from John Faucher from JPMorgan.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the concerns that I do hear from investors is a question sort of whether the cultures can merge and how you take something -- again, you guys have more of an operating culture versus the holding company culture. And can you talk a little bit about
componenttext: One of the concerns that I do hear from investors is a question sort of whether the cultures can merge and how you take something -- again, you guys have more of an operating culture versus the holding company culture. And can you talk a little bit about what you can learn from that standpoint and how you feel that, that sort of meshing of the 2 cultures within the organization is going to out?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, John, that our cultures are more similar than you might think. Maybe our business models are quite different, but when you engage when I engage with Jarden folks, we went out last night after getting ready for this call to little pop around t
componenttext: I would say, John, that our cultures are more similar than you might think. Maybe our business models are quite different, but when you engage when I engage with Jarden folks, we went out last night after getting ready for this call to little pop around the corner, we're watching the draft and there was a group of Newell people and group of Jarden people there. And they were -- there was a same dynamic as if this group have been together for a long time. This is a pretty operationally intense group of leaders that I've met so far, and so I don't think that's going to be the issue. The business models are different, so I think socializing the changes associated with that in the places where we choose to make change, I think, we'll be -- shouldn't be underestimated, but it won't be governed by culture. Our performance expectations -- our expectations are high for the combined entity. And so we all have to raise the bar. The performance that we delivered over the last number of the year well it has been pretty darn good relative to the industry and if you look at Martin and Tim's track record of value creation, we're way on the top of the league table. But the combination, we've said that we're going to be stronger together than either of us work apart, that's the rational for the deal. So expectations are high. Our performance needs to rise. Our expectations of each other need to be really high. And we will -- we need to align around that. I think that probably one of the most important mix of change management that have to happen quickly that looking backwards and judging performance cannot be forward-looking basis for what great looks like. Great has to look better than what we've done as individual companies in the past. And so we're going to raise the bar on each other and we're going to establish great clarity around what outcomes we're looking for. Growth is the engine that powers this company, and it has to be going forward. We're going to great great margin development through the synergies and by maximizing the mix through portfolio, the portfolio choices we work. But growth is undoubtedly the engine that's going to fire this company going forward. And we've guided 3% to 4%, which I think will be competitive results given the exits we'll likely embrace. But going forward, I think we can consistently deliver at the high end of that range once we get through this transitional period. And we need to put the building blocks in place as a company to deliver that, to sustain that, and maybe even beyond that going forward. And so, that's the change management piece of work that needs to happen, that's the social -- that's the messaging that needs to be embraced and people need to make the choice as to whether they are ready to enlist and line up behind that ambition which, I think based on what I see is going to be no problem. It's going to be very exciting, it's going to be also a lot of fun.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then 1 follow up would be sort of the top line synergy question in terms of you guys haven't really talked about that. Is it still to early to get a handle where you can drive more of the top line synergies? Or is that beginning to come into fo
componenttext: Great. And then 1 follow up would be sort of the top line synergy question in terms of you guys haven't really talked about that. Is it still to early to get a handle where you can drive more of the top line synergies? Or is that beginning to come into focus?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we're pretty clear about where those opportunities are. We talked about some of them outside. Depending on the rate of exit, some of that maybe get masked in those numbers, but we haven't built really any of that into the guidance we've provided at th
componenttext: No, we're pretty clear about where those opportunities are. We talked about some of them outside. Depending on the rate of exit, some of that maybe get masked in those numbers, but we haven't built really any of that into the guidance we've provided at this point. So to the degree that we can get that quickly, we'll get some upside to the numbers, so maybe we get to the high end of the range if we get the revenue synergies to start to crack. If you think about the revenue synergy, there are 3 buckets. Cross sell, the opportunity for cross-sell, the opportunity for accelerated international deployment and the opportunity to lead at the category level by applying the best of both companies capabilities to the category growth agenda. Those 3 are listed in the relative speed with which they are accessible. So channel cross sells accessible to us pretty much immediately just a question of getting customer alignment around taking assets from 1 business and putting them into channels than other businesses have access to. We've been divesting the most telegraphic example of that is the commentary we've shared on beverages taking Contigo, and Avex and Rubbermaid and thinking what portion of that portfolio is more relevant to the outdoor channel and leveraging Coleman selling systems to get -- and getting Coleman credit for selling the assets quite frankly. But letting them sell down there vertical brands like -- particularly Avex and Contigo, I would guess, and maybe bubba. And so that's an example of one thing that is available to us and there are many, many others like that. Those things come early. International cross sell probably takes us 6 to 9 months, maybe a little longer to get activated. And then just like the work that happened at Newell Rubbermaid, it took us 18 to 24 months to get a growth yield on the application of Newell's brand development design and innovation model. And where we apply that model within the Jarden portfolio, I would expect it takes that long to get impact as well. So there's a sequence of these 3 different buckets of revenue synergies with channel cross-sell offering the greatest opportunity in the near term.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, can we come back to the Jarden side of business sot he 2% organic sales growth in the quarter you said was in line with what you had expected. It was probably a shade below market expectation. Can you specifically talk a little bit about some of the
componenttext: Mike, can we come back to the Jarden side of business sot he 2% organic sales growth in the quarter you said was in line with what you had expected. It was probably a shade below market expectation. Can you specifically talk a little bit about some of the factors, understanding that it's a light seasonal quarter for Jarden. But talk specifically about the some of factors that are driving the slowdown. The comp did get considerably easier this quarter relative to last. And then maybe specifically talk a little bit about your line of sight here in terms of why things do get better to do the midpoint or the 3%, if you will, as comps do get tougher over the next couple quarters. And I have a follow up.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, no problem. So you're right, the Q4 growth rate that they had to comp, Q4 '14 [ph] growth rate was about 11.4% Q1 growth rate that the legacy Jarden business had to comp was about 4.7%. One of the big reasons this gets easier going forward is be
componenttext: Yes, yes, no problem. So you're right, the Q4 growth rate that they had to comp, Q4 '14 [ph] growth rate was about 11.4% Q1 growth rate that the legacy Jarden business had to comp was about 4.7%. One of the big reasons this gets easier going forward is because of the uncertainty, the veil of uncertainty that comes with the transaction like this that was overhanging the Jarden team in the first quarter goes away. We become human, accessible and involved. And so don't underestimate the impact of that on a business' ability to execute. So that's certainly an overhang in Q1 and that's why we were quite conservative and both business is quite conservative in the way they thought about the underlying performance. We've got momentum where it counts in the Jarden business number. You've got momentum in Yankee, you got momentum in JCS. Within some of the other segments or groups, you've got businesses that are looking quite interesting at the moment. You have some other factors that overhang the first quarter like the impact of a different kind of weather experience in the winter sports area and that's just the reality of mother nature that we've got to deal with, and so that clearly has some impact on some of the businesses. And while I won't get into very specific business unit numbers today, you can expect us going forward as we get into this to punctuate the specifics for you on a forward-looking basis. So why do things accelerate going forward? Things accelerate going forward because the uncertainty and the overhang on the organization connected to the combination of Newell and Jarden is behind us. We build enthusiasm behind the combination of the potential for Newell Brands. We engage and get into the details of the business and think about how we optimize the deployment of resources across the total portfolio that we plus up the winners and keep leaning our shoulders into them with more resource. We don't give up much, I don't think in certain other areas within Newell Rubbermaid, if we were to ship resources around and lean our shoulder into a couple of Jarden businesses. And then we get on with fixing some of the businesses that are underperforming. And while I won't get into the specifics within the Jarden portfolio, that is just a little bit premature to be talking about that sort of stuff publicly. We're going to get in. We do profit interventions when they are required. We did it in Baby,we did it on Europe with the Newell Rubbermaid, we're very public that we were doing it and you can count on us to articulate those when we're ready to. But think about the Baby business, Baby business was declining 10% in the first half of 2011 and then it was flat on the full year and we get that business back to 10% compounded growth in 2012, 2013. Last year, we grew 6-plus percent in that business. Last 2 quarters, around 9%. So when you get involved and get into the details and you unpack issues, you can fix them. And so there's a couple of businesses like that, that requires some intervention on the Jarden side and there are a couple of businesses on the Newell side that we're involved it. We talked about Tools and is starting to yield the outcomes we hope. And we'll keep our eye and apply the pressure and get involved and helped resolve some of the issues wherever they exist. And so it's a combination of those things that give us the confidence that we can get the right smacked up in the middle of the guidance range for the full year.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And the follow up, Mike, is on working capital. You've been very clear that your guidance doesn't assume any improvements there either on the Newell side or on the Jarden side. But when you screen the group, both Newell and Jarden co
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And the follow up, Mike, is on working capital. You've been very clear that your guidance doesn't assume any improvements there either on the Newell side or on the Jarden side. But when you screen the group, both Newell and Jarden come in bottom quartile relative to the consumer staples group, some of this maybe structural, but you also mentioned, too, it's a bit of focus. So operating cash flow will be a component of executive comp issue. Can you talk a little bit about the opportunity. I know it's been a race to the finish line to get the deal done, et cetera. Can you talk a little bit about the opportunity and whether that will be something you put the number on at some point in the future ?.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start where you ended, yes, we'll put a number on it in the future. If you look at the inventory days you say, "Man, there's an opportunity in both companies. " There is a structural difference so cannot benchmark companies that stores finished goo
componenttext: Let me start where you ended, yes, we'll put a number on it in the future. If you look at the inventory days you say, "Man, there's an opportunity in both companies. " There is a structural difference so cannot benchmark companies that stores finished goods against companies that are 100% salt manufactured. You'll never going to get the inventory days to kind of matchup. So you're naturally going to be longer and the reason that obviously makes sense is you don't have to fix the assets on your manufacturing base. So you accept a longer working capital ahead on inventory days for the sake of avoiding a fixed asset base. So they're always going to be longer. Do they need to be as long as they are? Absolutely not. There's absolutely no reason that we can't do better than we have up until now in the Newell Rubbermaid side, forecasting our business and having the confidence to call the upside and managing the flow of product along the entire value chain into inventories. So we've got work going on with respect to complexity reduction which will be an enabler to getting inventories down, but we haven't really lean our shoulder into that yet. I think we have an opportunity to extend the payables as well, both sides and we're going to focus on that as part of our procurement work. So we have a lot of leverage to pull on working capital. Cash matters a ton. It always has, but it really does over the next couple of years and it always should because cash going forward, once you get delevered, becomes the complementary investment tool we've got to strengthen our aggregate performance on top of what we hope to be a very strong organic performance. And so it matters a ton. We're going to do this. This is the bit that we haven't focused on as much as we could and we're going to get it right. And we'll put some numbers around it so you can hold us accountable for problem.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Bill Schmitz of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next question comes from Bill Schmitz of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about some of the milestones and dates for some of the typical merger integrations in block?  So when you'll have the pro forma management structure, the GB structures, may be the employment contract to make sure you keep full. And then
componenttext: Can you just talk about some of the milestones and dates for some of the typical merger integrations in block?  So when you'll have the pro forma management structure, the GB structures, may be the employment contract to make sure you keep full. And then when are you going to decide who's going to cover the key accounts and who's going to have to leave. And then lastly, just when you'll have the full systems over?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, structure follows strategies. The strategy work on portfolio for the summer is really important first step in getting to -- having a discussion about organization design, route to market, all those things. So I thank you should not expect this
componenttext: Yes. Well, structure follows strategies. The strategy work on portfolio for the summer is really important first step in getting to -- having a discussion about organization design, route to market, all those things. So I thank you should not expect this to move over the summer on choices like that. Top leadership team coming together. There's a question before on supply chain. We're in the market looking for supply chain leader in the total company. We hope to get that done over the next couple of months. And we're forming and storming the teams now. With respect to our business unit leaders, I feel pretty good about their engagement, so I don't think there's huge risk there. And with respect to the org design, again, it will flow from the portfolio of choices which will come out of the August board meeting and we'll make some decisions on how exactly we wanted -- how exactly we apply the agreements we get there and what choices we make. I wouldn't expect us to do at all in 1 swing. I think you should think about us applying some of the work, getting experience with what our set of pretty intuitive combinations you would expect from us and then learning from that and moving sequentially. I think one of the most important things we've got to do is leverage our scale and channels and geographies. And so that will inform -- and customers. That will inform the some of the things we think about as well.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And how about the systems cutover ?
componenttext: Okay. And how about the systems cutover ?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And systems, we've got 32 different ERP systems within Jarden -- legacy Jarden. So this is going to be very important part of our overall integration work. There's a whole work stream around this. We'll -- I think we'll end up providing great visibility t
componenttext: And systems, we've got 32 different ERP systems within Jarden -- legacy Jarden. So this is going to be very important part of our overall integration work. There's a whole work stream around this. We'll -- I think we'll end up providing great visibility to you over time. Of all the work streams, I'm very happy exposing where the work is happening. It's a little early to do that, but you should expect us to be getting to -- to balancing the kind of cash investments required against the return but getting to a streamlined level of ERP system such that information flow happens more systemically as opposed to having human intervention drive the flow of information. And we very successfully did that on Newell and we are now went live on SAP in Asia Pacific in the first quarter, actually in April and released to 4 or 5 countries in Asia Pacific and we'll sequentially fill out the rest of the map over the balance of this year and Newell will effectively be done, Russia and Turkey, 2 outliers. But on balance, 99% on the same ERP systems. So we'll begin to take that one as well as part of our agenda. We have not counted on any cost synergies yet from that work and this will be an area that likely falls into the second tranche of savings beyond the first $500 million.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. I think right now, you have a daily sales dashbroad at Newell. Do you have the same thing for Jarden ?
componenttext: Got you. I think right now, you have a daily sales dashbroad at Newell. Do you have the same thing for Jarden ?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's called 1 (800), I don't need one -- first of all, I shouldn't be doing that. I got to confess to you that's probably not what a CEO should be doing. But I do like it junkie for the datum because numbers are always been words to me, but we don't
componenttext: Yes, it's called 1 (800), I don't need one -- first of all, I shouldn't be doing that. I got to confess to you that's probably not what a CEO should be doing. But I do like it junkie for the datum because numbers are always been words to me, but we don't have that today at Jarden, but we have early sophisticated connected process where if I wanted it, I could probably get it. But that dashboard doesn't exist today in that dynamical way. But it didn't exist at Newell Rubbermaid when we started either, we built it.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one last quick one. I mean, I think the Jarden employees are reasonably more highly compensated than some of the legacy Newell guys so are you willing to sort of pay out to keep the critical people and sort of, what does that mean for the broad
componenttext: Okay. Just one last quick one. I mean, I think the Jarden employees are reasonably more highly compensated than some of the legacy Newell guys so are you willing to sort of pay out to keep the critical people and sort of, what does that mean for the broader company ?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've kept everything the same on the Jarden side in 2016 and we will when the grants come for leaders coming out of the May Board meeting. It will be exactly what they would have expected had the transaction not occurred. And you just have to accept
componenttext: Yes, we've kept everything the same on the Jarden side in 2016 and we will when the grants come for leaders coming out of the May Board meeting. It will be exactly what they would have expected had the transaction not occurred. And you just have to accept that there are differences over time. We'll figure out how to bring the companies together. Our principles are going to be very simple, we're going to pay people at the median of the pay -- that the 50th percentile pay and we're going to when we need extraordinary talent and key roles, critical roles, tend to get paid more. And that's fine. I don't have any issues with that. But our principles are that we pay the -- pay the 50th percentile. And for extraordinary talent and critical roles, we go higher than that. But of course, you can make a lot of money here if you perform. The whole comp philosophy for the company is you can double up basically if you just outperform your objectives. And so people can make a lot of money in Newell Rubbermaid side if they nailed their numbers, and that's the philosophy we'll embed. We want to embed a pay-for-performance culture. I don't think it's really that dissimilar. This is certainly a pay-for-performance culture on the Jarden side as well. The mechanisms are different, and so we'll overtime get that sorted.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And moving on, we'll hear next from Wendy Nicholson of Citi.
componenttext: And moving on, we'll hear next from Wendy Nicholson of Citi.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. First on the Writing business. This is 2 quarters in a row where we've seen the margin come down and I know you called the Elmer's seasonality as well as currency headwinds. But can you just kind of remind us your outlook for
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. First on the Writing business. This is 2 quarters in a row where we've seen the margin come down and I know you called the Elmer's seasonality as well as currency headwinds. But can you just kind of remind us your outlook for the full year? Do you think operating margins for the Writing segment kind of net of the China expansion which -- by the way, could you comment if that's still on track? Are margins for the Writing segment kind of be where they were last year or you think it will be down for the full year ?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me -- I'll deal with both of those. Let me deal with the second question first. So China is on track for a Q4 launch, start of marketing around Back-to-School, which is in February 2017, but the pipeline and route to market work in the fourth
componenttext: Yes, so let me -- I'll deal with both of those. Let me deal with the second question first. So China is on track for a Q4 launch, start of marketing around Back-to-School, which is in February 2017, but the pipeline and route to market work in the fourth quarter of '16 which is where we've always had it planned and very excited about the prospects. Sharpie and Paper Mate into 1 big market, which is in Shanghai. So really looking forward to that and we're excited about the potential of our Writing business in China over time. So that's fine and progressing and Christie and Vick who are the -- Christie who is President of the Writing segment. And Vic Masala, who is the SVP of the writing brand development, are working hand-in-hand to get the launch to occur. So that's right on track. With respect to writing margins, we're going to continue to invest in writing. The Elmer's, I'll make sure Nancy gets back to you on what exactly the Elmer's impact has been on margin for the Writing segment. It's pretty material. And other thing that you have to remember is that in our public numbers, we have Venezuela in the year-ago period. And in the current period, we don't. The Venezuelan margins were higher than fleet average margins. So I wouldn't want you to think about this us being willing to accept margin decline. These are structural mix related issues in the year-over-year numbers. We help people accountable for margin development on a peg rate basis so while we reported actual rates, people's incentive structures are based on constant currency and we're doing fine in that respect although I would tell you that as we extend the shoulders of the business into new geographies, there's going to be a E& investment requirement that will dilute operating margins for a period of time. But you know how we operate. We're happy to do that for a period of time if we get the growth yield and we'll pull that money out. Move it somewhere else at some point in the future. You saw that on the Baby business in terms of the operating margins development in Baby in the first quarter. There's also a currency related impact given how we source componentry related to the yen dollar that's impacting gross margins. We don't want to price for that. So we've got the some inside baseball thing that contributed to that that are sort of external factor related that we don't always choose the price to recover. So I'm not stressed about Writing margins at all. We've got a big project going on and writing complexity that will enhance margins going forward -- gross margins going forward and I think that's probably something that we should eliminate for you guys going -- over the next 6 to 9 months when we talk about writing capacity. But to understand the manufacturing footprint, the changes we're making there, that might bring some color to the margin development forward-looking story.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that all sounds fair. But that sort of concept or complexity, if you will, leads me to my second question which is kind of a follow up to the discussion about the product line exits. And I guess, number one, I didn't hear your clarify all the --- le
componenttext: Okay, that all sounds fair. But that sort of concept or complexity, if you will, leads me to my second question which is kind of a follow up to the discussion about the product line exits. And I guess, number one, I didn't hear your clarify all the --- let's call it $300 million. How much is in the core business versus how much is Jarden? Have you done that?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we got a pretty good perspective. I'd say the majority will be on the Jarden side, but it's not unsubstantial amount that potentially could be on the Newell Rubbermaid side. So you know we're  continuing to do the work on Consumer Storage. We're
componenttext: Yes. No, we got a pretty good perspective. I'd say the majority will be on the Jarden side, but it's not unsubstantial amount that potentially could be on the Newell Rubbermaid side. So you know we're  continuing to do the work on Consumer Storage. We're not done with that yet. There are some aspects of our Baby business that could benefit us to pull back on. So there's bits and pieces. There's some things in consumer cleaning within the Rubbermaid brand as we get Rubbermaid more focused around food, storage, food preservation, food on the go where the margins -- we have to go through the full work of understanding how cost get allocated the business to understand the real underlying profitability of cash impact of these businesses. But those are all areas that we're going to intensely focus on to understand whether certain aspects of the Rubbermaid business might be better served exiting and Baby as well. So still some opportunity in Baby Europe in particular. So these are things we go after. Now on the Jarden side, just don't want to declare too early until we get into this a little bit more deeply with them, but there are perspectives we've got coming out of the first couple of weeks and a couple of months prior to that, that are worth reflecting on.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's my sort of last question, my sort of philosophical question, which is you've said very clearly that you got a ton of work to do and it sounds like you get specific plans and timing for completing that work and articulating to us and all that ki
componenttext: And that's my sort of last question, my sort of philosophical question, which is you've said very clearly that you got a ton of work to do and it sounds like you get specific plans and timing for completing that work and articulating to us and all that kind of stuff. So I'm a little surprised that you would tell us a number at all at this point because I would think that if anything that number let's call it $200 million product line exits from Jarden, is it a risk of going up significantly? And I was curious as to why you chose to give us that number today? Because I would imagine the product line impact up in the second quarter is going to be relatively minimal and it just seems like it's a number that's -- could be awfully premature.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a fair question, it's a good question. So as you undoubtedly know about us, we don't just sort of pull numbers out, we build them from bottom-up. And so we have a pretty clear sense of what we do. I just think it would be premature to declare t
componenttext: Well, it's a fair question, it's a good question. So as you undoubtedly know about us, we don't just sort of pull numbers out, we build them from bottom-up. And so we have a pretty clear sense of what we do. I just think it would be premature to declare that. These are businesses that are probably unsellable. That doesn't mean there are other businesses that you might think about from a portfolio management perspective going forward. So it's just 1 piece of the puzzle. And then as I said, our inclination to try to fix businesses. So this doesn't mean these are the only businesses that are margin challenged. So then the question becomes why share that this early? Because I want to set guidance expectations on core sales growth and because how we define core sales growth versus how organic sales growth was defined, it's important for us to pivot from the 3% to 5% organic guidance to the 2% to 4% core guidance on the Jarden businesses and explain that and give you the reasons why we're doing that, and that's because organic sales excluded the impact of product line exits and core sales includes the impact of product line exits. So being explicit in saying that we we're exiting $250 million to $300 million of business over the next 2 to 3 years gives you some ability to understand -- a better ability to understand the core sales assumptions and not get freaked out about the fact that we might be guiding down on Jarden. We're not at all doing that. What we're doing is, we're going to -- saying we're going to get one approach, the guiding underlying performance in the business which is the core sales number. And that's the mechanism by which we do it. So fair question though, Wendy, and I appreciate it, respect it and you can count on us to get quite specific shortly.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Joe Altobello from Raymond James.
componenttext: Next question comes from Joe Altobello from Raymond James.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question, Mike, and obviously, it's still early. You guys have only owned Jarden now for only 2 weeks here. But I should look at organization and the structure there and you think about the plan you guys are going to present to the board in the c
componenttext: So first question, Mike, and obviously, it's still early. You guys have only owned Jarden now for only 2 weeks here. But I should look at organization and the structure there and you think about the plan you guys are going to present to the board in the coming summer. How similar is the playbook that you guys have in place for Jarden compared to what you had 5 years ago when you first got to Newell ?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a little bit different in that the Newell Rubbermaid business wasn't growing when we started. So you got a different scenario where you got both Newell Rubbermaid and Jarden legacy businesses growing nicely. So the context is a little bit different.
componenttext: It's a little bit different in that the Newell Rubbermaid business wasn't growing when we started. So you got a different scenario where you got both Newell Rubbermaid and Jarden legacy businesses growing nicely. So the context is a little bit different. The application of the capability agenda is going to be really exciting. I think the work -- the legacy Jarden folks have done on direct-to-consumer e-commerce is really exciting. I just got an e-mail from Paul's team on Yankee Candle and I called my daughters right away because you can customize Yankee candle jar with pictures of your family for Mother's Day. I was like, "Girls, we go tit -- if we want to get it delivered by Mother's day, we got to do it this weekend. " That's just brilliant and we don't do that. We we're thinking that creatively under direct-to-consumer e-commerce front. And so there's some stuff on that side that's so applicable. I just got -- I ordered one of the first things I did was order a built online, a customized rolling baseball. And I just got it 2 weeks ago. And it's so exciting. My wife saw it. My wife don't even know anything about baseball wants a baseball mitt customized for her. So there's some really thing Jarden has done but we haven't been that creative about on the Newell Rubbermaid side. We have tremendous opportunity to apply that capability. On the other side, we have a terrific design and innovation machine going now on Newell Rubbermaid. 5.6 core sales growth is a big number when 75% of your revenues in the U.S., in U.S. GDP growth is 0.5%. Now why are we growing 5.6% ? is because we've got these innovations that are coming through the funnel and hanging I the marketplace with impact. We can apply that capability to many aspects of the Jarden portfolio and you should expect us to apply that. Now that's the Newell playbook working for Jarden and the Jarden playbook working for Newell. So the best of both capabilities, applied across the total portfolio is what we're going to go do with a real passion around brands and growth. This idea that growth is the engine that fires this company is really important for people to embrace. And we mean growth through brilliant commercial execution and to brilliant brand development and we're going to do both of those. And I think when we're done and we look back for the benefit of the 3, or 4, or 5 to 6, 7 years, we'll say, man, we really didn't do what they said by taking the best of both talent pools and the best of both capabilities and applying them as broadly as they are relevant across the portfolio. It doesn't mean and we're more sophisticated than this. It does not mean that every capability is applicable to every business, and that's fine. And it doesn't disable the scale leverage that we've got through the combination when you accept that. It's just smart management. And so, you should expect us to push hard to make the company leaner and meaner, to scale functions for efficiency in the business partnering areas and to scale functions for impact across the total enterprise for growth. But we're going to maintain intimacy at the point of demand creation which is where the selling happens and where the consumer engages with our brands. And if you step back from all design type of concepts and focus on principles, that's the type of thing that will inform choices, on specific design choices and that's what's going to drive us. This is a company -- when we get the brand search back for the summer, I suspect and we exposed it to you, you're going to be blown away by the quality of the brands in this portfolio. I was within the Newell Rubbermaid relative to brands I've worked on before and I've worked on great brands. Worked on Oreo, I've worked on Dove, I've worked on Axe, I've worked on Ritz, I've worked on Maxwell House, I worked on great brands, Kraft. But these brands are really way stronger than people perceive them to be and I suspect that when we get the brand equity work back on brands like Oster and brands like Yankee and brands like Rawlings, brands like for Coleman, you'll see these great assets. Some of them perhaps latent and underleveraged but great assets just like we saw on Newell Rubbermaid, Graco. Graco by far the highest equity score of any brand I've worked on, higher than Dove.  So my energy level is really high because I'm so excited by unlocking the possibilities here with the teams. And I'm really excited about the prospects of us applying the best of what both companies have to offer across the total portfolio.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. It's very helpful. And then just one last housekeeping question first dip. In terms of the tax rate, 29% to 30% this year, is that a good tax rate to use going forward or is there more of an opportunity to get that down to more of the legacy Newel
componenttext: Got it. It's very helpful. And then just one last housekeeping question first dip. In terms of the tax rate, 29% to 30% this year, is that a good tax rate to use going forward or is there more of an opportunity to get that down to more of the legacy Newell tax rate?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we didn't build in anything in our synergies, Joe, for getting the tax rate down. But you should expect us to run like hell to get a better rate based upon what we've done on the Newell side. So I would tell you there's certainly some upside that we've
componenttext: So we didn't build in anything in our synergies, Joe, for getting the tax rate down. But you should expect us to run like hell to get a better rate based upon what we've done on the Newell side. So I would tell you there's certainly some upside that we've already started the work on trying to figure out how to bring some of the Jarden stuff into our structure and so far to try to maximize the structure for the new entity.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That said, Joe, I wouldn't take the old guidance that we had on Newell Rubbermaid for around 23-ish percent rate. I think we'll find the opportunities like John said, they're going to be plenty of them. But I would assume that we're going to get them grad
componenttext: That said, Joe, I wouldn't take the old guidance that we had on Newell Rubbermaid for around 23-ish percent rate. I think we'll find the opportunities like John said, they're going to be plenty of them. But I would assume that we're going to get them gradually as supposed to overnight.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we have Olivia Tong with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Next, we have Olivia Tong with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on the Jarden organic sales, you guys are pretty explicit that the 2% to 4% is the 2016 target. But can you talk about what you think -- do you think you can get back to the same target of 3% to 5%? Is that the run right run rate on the going forwa
componenttext: First, on the Jarden organic sales, you guys are pretty explicit that the 2% to 4% is the 2016 target. But can you talk about what you think -- do you think you can get back to the same target of 3% to 5%? Is that the run right run rate on the going forward for 2017 on? And then in terms of the businesses that are slated for sale, are you going to start characterizing your businesses -- the Jarden businesses into sort of Win Bigger versus incubate I categories to give us visibility into how you think about different businesses like you did when you first came to Newell ?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me start with the last part. I think you should count on us to articulate for you portfolio roles coming out of -- coming into the fall will be the position we probably talked to that. We wont use the same language this is a whole new company
componenttext: Yes, so let me start with the last part. I think you should count on us to articulate for you portfolio roles coming out of -- coming into the fall will be the position we probably talked to that. We wont use the same language this is a whole new company for both sides and so we'll brand it maybe a little bit differently, but it's same basic, where to play choices and we'll realign, obviously, the portfolio choices to the new portfolio. So yes the answer to that piece of the question. Your question in 2017 guidance, we haven't guided 2017 growth. I will tell you though that the $250 million to $300 million of exits that we've talked about were over 2 to 3 years. And if you do the math on that, you see those exits will cover the opportunity to break out on the high end, probably through 2017. So what is the right long term guidance? We haven't gotten to that yet. I want to go through the work over the summer. We'll pull together an integrated forward-looking model that gives you that long-term guidance. You can capture some of that through the comments I was making through 2018 on cash and cash capital allocation. You back into some of the numbers that we chose to. But I wouldn't want to begin to articulate the acceleration stage metrics. It's just too early.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on A&P, up 40 basis points, still very strong improvements but perhaps even not as aggressive as you were last year. So is this is a function of the base getting bigger or is there something timing of initiatives? And how do you think abo
componenttext: Got it. And then on A&P, up 40 basis points, still very strong improvements but perhaps even not as aggressive as you were last year. So is this is a function of the base getting bigger or is there something timing of initiatives? And how do you think about the spent for the remainder of the year?

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, I think, we make -- no, it depends on how we allocate A&P across a total portfolio. But if we have been -- if Newell Rubbermaid have been a standalone company this year, we would have increased A&P bps, at least as much as we increased them last
componenttext: Actually, I think, we make -- no, it depends on how we allocate A&P across a total portfolio. But if we have been -- if Newell Rubbermaid have been a standalone company this year, we would have increased A&P bps, at least as much as we increased them last year in 2016. So I guided to 5.5% if you remember in the fall A&P ratio. We delivered about 5% so we'll have another 50 bps in the full year and I think you should assume that's a good number in your base case assumptions about the legacy Newell Rubbermaid businesses. If we do choose to spend some of the renewal savings back on brands like Yankee or Oster, we'll let you know so that you can adjust your models.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from Jason Gere with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our final question comes from Jason Gere with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Newell Rubbermaid Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
