componenttext: Quarterly, in '17, we'll be able to principally because of the divestiture so the timing, not exactly. So the team expect this to should expect this to be active.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, we just need to get the transition organizationally behind us. We get the next quarter under our belts, operating as a new team. But of course, you can control timing on these things, side of the whether there will be first half, second half early
componenttext: Steve, we just need to get the transition organizationally behind us. We get the next quarter under our belts, operating as a new team. But of course, you can control timing on these things, side of the whether there will be first half, second half early late, we don't know. But job one is to get the transition behind us and start operating in the new context in delivering the new context and the M&A will present itself when it does.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kevin Grundy from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin Grundy from Jefferies.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I wanted to come back to the topic of core sales. And I guess, I was sort of informs our be with underlying trends. So year reported 3% in the quarter, Bill Chappell sort of touched on this sort of dynamics as well. In Q3 your guide for the lower en
componenttext: Mike, I wanted to come back to the topic of core sales. And I guess, I was sort of informs our be with underlying trends. So year reported 3% in the quarter, Bill Chappell sort of touched on this sort of dynamics as well. In Q3 your guide for the lower end of 3% to 4%, but that was prior to the decision to exclude the divestitures that you announced. And I heard from that probably rough math probably in the ballpark of like 50 to 100 basis points. So my sense is market expectations and dollars were closer to 4% in the quarter given that dynamic. And presumably, I guess, even probably I suspect lower than your expectations also given this dynamic. So is that accurate, number one? And I guess, number two, if so, what sort of came in worse in the quarter than you anticipated then when you gave the guidance of lower end of 3% to 4%, and then I have a follow-up.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a fair a question, Kevin. So the things that I'm looking at is am looking at the net sales numbers relative to what you guys have a new models, and we're off a bit. And I think part of that is driven by other performance in the held-for-sale business
componenttext: It's a fair a question, Kevin. So the things that I'm looking at is am looking at the net sales numbers relative to what you guys have a new models, and we're off a bit. And I think part of that is driven by other performance in the held-for-sale businesses relative to what you expected. And to be fair, some of those businesses underperformed our expectations as well. If you follow the Stanley discussion when they were talking about the deal, they talked about a distribution transition issue in Tool -- our Tools business that they were aware of, and we disclosed. And so we had -- the held-for-sale businesses underperforming slightly. The balance of the business came in pretty much where we thought it was going to be. I debated back with Q2 earnings given you guys some of these moving parts that I've now disclosed like a didn't think I would be a better be talking about our SPRUE relationship in the U.K., but I think it's worth talking about. You have a whole series -- and I didn't talk to you about the beverage DC transition because I don't think it was were talking about. But it was kind of hoping that we would have gotten 20, 30, 40 basis points more, but that's $12 million in the quarter, so it's not something I spent a lot of time worrying about. But beverages, there are whole series of onetime things that we just chose to model right on through that their beverages DC, the SPRUE event continuing to see that the Commercial Products transition all the way through. These are choices that are the right choices for the long haul, but they compromise year end type of delivery. And we just accepted that risk associated with the guidance. But your rough math is right, but they were just -- they were roughly the same amount of onetime negatives in the business that we're working against the number you quoted. So all of that was within our line of sight, maybe we're hoping for a little bit better or less profound impacts there, but it's on the fringes when you think about what else we were worrying about in the quarter. We were worried about disposing $1.5 billion worth of business, we were resetting the entire organization, including the sales force, which is not a small deal to do when you're -- as U.S.-centric as we are. So our focus was on the longer time frame and in a perfect world, we would have delivered 3.5, 4, but in the context of what we were doing, we wanted to see the other stuff through that could have mitigated the risk, and we chose to take a longer than 90-day view on some of those choices. You could easily defer the transition and beverages, you could have easily defer some  of the other choices we're making on complexity to flatter core numbers, but we just didn't in the context of the kind of profound change we're driving just didn't want to create that complexity in the organization. So we chose to ignore it and let the numbers play the way they were going to play.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate the transparency on that, Mike. And one more follow up for me as it pertains to underlying business trends, so you asked of your organic sales guidance like rough math now to 3.5% to 4% you've done 4.2% if I'm not mistaken year-to-date
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate the transparency on that, Mike. And one more follow up for me as it pertains to underlying business trends, so you asked of your organic sales guidance like rough math now to 3.5% to 4% you've done 4.2% if I'm not mistaken year-to-date for core sales. So the rough math sort of suggest the high end, you do 3.5 core sales in 4Q where the low end will be like sub-2 kind of number. But given the comment you just made like 3.5% probably would've and what we would like to have done what you made some longer term decisions for the business which is sensible. Should we be thinking about higher end? That feels like a reasonable place to be, correct me if I'm wrong.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, here's what -- in the script, what I said was that within the core sales guidance range, we're trending towards the higher end. And so back at the Back-to-School I guided Q3 to the low end and I even said in some of the Q&A that I'd be fine if we tr
componenttext: Well, here's what -- in the script, what I said was that within the core sales guidance range, we're trending towards the higher end. And so back at the Back-to-School I guided Q3 to the low end and I even said in some of the Q&A that I'd be fine if we trip to below. In Q4, I said midpoint of the range and at the midpoint of the range, you end up at 3.8, 3.9 on a full year. There are things happening in the fourth quarter and up try to be transparent about it in some of the answer I gave earlier. We will have softer baby momentum in the fourth quarter connected to the distributor transition in Canada. We will have slower Writing growth, sort of a very low end of the range connected to the complexity reduction, a manufacturing transition and a distribution transition in the fourth quarter, and that's all driven by the choices we're making to get the complexity out of that business. This is the right time of year to do it so that when we come up in Q1 and into Q2 ramping for Back-to-School '17, we're in full flight.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With better margins.
componenttext: With better margins.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With better margins like we saw on the Commercial Products margins that we recorded, 250 basis point improved margins. Now in the case of writing, we'll likely spend that money back. But in the case of Commercial Products, we banked that. And so -- and we
componenttext: With better margins like we saw on the Commercial Products margins that we recorded, 250 basis point improved margins. Now in the case of writing, we'll likely spend that money back. But in the case of Commercial Products, we banked that. And so -- and we're going to have really strong Home Solutions growth in the fourth quarter connected to the recovery of beverages after the distribution center transition related to the launch of Brilliance on Rubbermaid and related to a shift in timing on cookware out of Q3 to Q4, which again, we don't talk about, shouldn't talk about because it's just too much inside baseball information. But we're going to have a really strong top line quarter in the fourth quarter. So we'll have very strong Home Solutions, weak writing low end of the range of what you would be comfortable with connected to the writing complexity work. We'll have the baby transition that will costs us of $5 million to $10 million of revenue in the fourth quarter, but set up great growth next year on baby. We'll have strong performance on appliances, we'll have should a very good Yankee performance in the fourth quarter given that we're spending more. So the complexion of our growth in the fourth quarter will change versus what has been driving as up until now. But again, '16 is a reset year to be able to set up or set up year to set up this movement forward in '17, and we're going to see all that through. I think mid point of the range is the right place to peg yourself and I've given very specific perspective on what I think the earnings per share will look like in the fourth quarter because we're going to spend significantly more A&P behind the growth agenda in the fourth quarter.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're a few years now into higher advertising spending on the heritage Newell business at obviously seems to have worked in terms of driving sustainably higher organic sales growth, along with I guess, the innovation you discussed earlier in Q&A. But any
componenttext: We're a few years now into higher advertising spending on the heritage Newell business at obviously seems to have worked in terms of driving sustainably higher organic sales growth, along with I guess, the innovation you discussed earlier in Q&A. But any initial thoughts on how response of the Jarden side of the portfolio might be the higher marketing spending versus heritage Newell, maybe some early reads in businesses where you boost the marketing or have you done [indiscernible] Jarden side at least some of the analytics you've run through post the deal to determine where to spend.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're going to learn to really quickly here because we're putting material money behind Yankee in the fourth quarter. We've gotten new advertising that the teams worked on, and we're going to try to stimulate more demand around the customization promis
componenttext: So we're going to learn to really quickly here because we're putting material money behind Yankee in the fourth quarter. We've gotten new advertising that the teams worked on, and we're going to try to stimulate more demand around the customization promise that Yankee can make through broad-based television advertising as we come to the holidays. Because of Yankee's retail footprint, we'll be able to measure that really quickly. So I'm actually excited to be able to see -- pull a lever and get a response that is tangible hopefully. We'll learn quickly because as you know, we don't want to put money into businesses that aren't going to have that kind of responsiveness. And we haven't done that up until now. We've been quite commercial through Q2 and Q3 on Jarden investment, but the money is now being shifted over to Yankee as part of our portfolio and prioritization work, and we should learn very, very quickly fourth quarter into Q1 as to whether that worked or didn't work. And we're kind of hopeful that it will. So time will tell. It's right around the corner we've got all eyes on this up because obviously, we'd love to grow without having to make big investments in A&P, but we believe actually that the E&P is sort of in an essential part of the algorithm for Newell Rubbermaid and the categories look very, very similar. So we think that one of the things that the scale and the combination affords us is to be able to put this type of A&P behind some of higher-priority businesses with the goal of trying to dwarf from a resourcing standpoint our subscale competition. And now the learner fourth quarter, so right around quarter.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then heritage Newell side, I guess, where the instruments very strong results. Are you seeing any competitive response out there in terms of advertising or promotional spending that as we look out to 2017 could slow the momentum?
componenttext: Okay. And then heritage Newell side, I guess, where the instruments very strong results. Are you seeing any competitive response out there in terms of advertising or promotional spending that as we look out to 2017 could slow the momentum?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not right. Right now, not really. We've seen mostly commercial responses, not big investments. It's going to be very hard for subscale competition to be able to afford to put money into the brands the way we are. That's part of the path -- this is wha
componenttext: No, not right. Right now, not really. We've seen mostly commercial responses, not big investments. It's going to be very hard for subscale competition to be able to afford to put money into the brands the way we are. That's part of the path -- this is what scale matters in these categories. So we haven't seen material shifts in investment profiles or material shifts in the quality of the innovations that are coming to market.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last, are there other pieces of the portfolio under on the Jarden renewal said which could be a candidate for divestiture post what you've already announced? Are they sizable, or are you pretty comfortable with the portfolio at this point R
componenttext: Okay. And then last, are there other pieces of the portfolio under on the Jarden renewal said which could be a candidate for divestiture post what you've already announced? Are they sizable, or are you pretty comfortable with the portfolio at this point RBC assuming these divestiture occur?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I never like to kind of make it black and white then we'll never do it. But we took a big swing here with the choices we've made in August, and we're going to see all those through. There may be other assets over time that we've swapped for some other ite
componenttext: I never like to kind of make it black and white then we'll never do it. But we took a big swing here with the choices we've made in August, and we're going to see all those through. There may be other assets over time that we've swapped for some other items in the core, but we're not active in that regard, we've got a lot in our plate right now, executing what we said we're going to do. And I think I wouldn't envision anything material happening over the next 2 or 3 quarters. And beyond that, I'd hesitate to get too specific. But we actively manage the portfolio, and we have Rubbermaid. We'll continue on the combination. Our energy now is focused on disposals, it's going to shift in bolt-on M&A in the core. There may be some other things we chose to do later on but for now, we're really happy with what we've chosen to do, and we think that will enable management and leadership to focus on the businesses with the greatest opportunity.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on a tax rate, the 26%, 27% for fiscal 2017, thereafter do you think the tax rate stays at that level, or does it jump back up? And then I have a question on e-commerce.
componenttext: Just a quick question on a tax rate, the 26%, 27% for fiscal 2017, thereafter do you think the tax rate stays at that level, or does it jump back up? And then I have a question on e-commerce.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wendy, on the tax rate for 26%, 27% for '17, what that reflects is some of that tax planning that we've started actually and sort of realize benefit from as early as this quarter and the balance of the year. So that we think is sustainable. Those of tax p
componenttext: Wendy, on the tax rate for 26%, 27% for '17, what that reflects is some of that tax planning that we've started actually and sort of realize benefit from as early as this quarter and the balance of the year. So that we think is sustainable. Those of tax planning things that taking advantage of with the combined footprint of Jarden and Newell on a global basis so sustainable. There are things that we're going to be I'll call attacking in terms of more tax optimization over time and I think as we evolve the company in the M&A agenda as well, that presents additional opportunities. So I think that's the right range to model beyond. I don't see it lifting materially from '17.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly don't pick '18 as well because there's going to be more tax synergies. One of the beautiful thing about this is, there are this discrete items, obviously, because of the discrete items in Q3. We've assumed that we're able to repeat some of
componenttext: Yes, certainly don't pick '18 as well because there's going to be more tax synergies. One of the beautiful thing about this is, there are this discrete items, obviously, because of the discrete items in Q3. We've assumed that we're able to repeat some of these discrete items, there'll be different discrete items, but we'll able to cover that in the base., but the going tax benefits will -- should, as Ralph just said, increase over time. That said, if you look out a few years beyond that, there's some potential that the tax rate could drift up. But I've been saying that the whole time I've been at Newell Rubbermaid, and it hasn't actually played out that way. So I always worry about the discrete items not being able to lap them, but there's always seem to be more discrete items available.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Terrific. Sounds good. And then on eCommerce, and my question, I guess, 2 things sort of conceptually the idea of pulling together an eCommerce Division, they're going to focus in everything from e-commerce sales to digital marketing and all that kind of
componenttext: Terrific. Sounds good. And then on eCommerce, and my question, I guess, 2 things sort of conceptually the idea of pulling together an eCommerce Division, they're going to focus in everything from e-commerce sales to digital marketing and all that kind of stuff am I assume, correct me if I'm wrong. But the $1 billion of sales through e-commerce channels, how much of that do you expect will be through your own website, to your direct-to-consumer, or is that all going to be through independent retail websites? And is that going to be margin accretive or dilutive to the existing margin?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me clear about that. This is a commercial organization so this is a selling and demand conversion organization so they will not be spending the vast majority of their time in digital market that would be the brand book with organization people that
componenttext: So let me clear about that. This is a commercial organization so this is a selling and demand conversion organization so they will not be spending the vast majority of their time in digital market that would be the brand book with organization people that will be creating the digital assets and thinking about the digital media strategy. So the brand owners will own that work. This is a group of people that will be focused, and it will be a sizable group of people who will be focused on taking the demand created by the brand teams and converting it to purchase in these channels. And their focus is going to be largely brick-and-mortar.com and pure-play.com. We do not envision a huge movement forward on Director consumer, except in the Yankee business and then selected other businesses like Marmot and potentially Coleman and Baby. But the reality is that the vast majority of that growth is going to come bricks-and-mortar.com and pure-play.com. And so the selling aspects around Amazon, the pure play or Ali Baba as a pure play, or walmart.com as a pure play, that will be led by this team and they'll be working in partnership with the bricks-and-mortar teams to drive conversion of demand, the purchase and the channel. It's going to be really, really exciting. The $1 billion growth, I think, is conservative in terms of what's possible by 2020, but we're ramping that capability now and the hub of that organization will be 1 floor below the executive team in Hoboken. So we're going to keep that team right next to us because of the importance of its delivery against our growth agenda.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the margin profile of that $1 billion of sales?
componenttext: And the margin profile of that $1 billion of sales?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually just depends on what happens going forward. Today,.com margins are generally better than brick-and-mortar margins because you have lower selling expense connected to it. If you think most companies have about 4% selling expense and consumer
componenttext: It's actually just depends on what happens going forward. Today,.com margins are generally better than brick-and-mortar margins because you have lower selling expense connected to it. If you think most companies have about 4% selling expense and consumer good space to be able to reach brick-and-mortar, you've got far less intensity because you don't have retail selling expense either brokered or direct-to-retail selling expense connected to it. So it can be -- it's about parity of growth, but it's brought more profitable through the below the line aspects of it.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: So why is it organic growth in the fourth quarter going to better? Because if you look at the puts and takes, it sounds like air bed is going back into Walmart. Yankee is not lapping the pipeline [indiscernible] make more advertising. The pen business is shipping in China and if you look at Jarden's comp and it goes from like a plus 6 this quarter to a plus 2 and yours is roughly the same. So am I missing something there? I know you have a little bit of headwind on the skewed reduction in the baby stuff?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's the right thing to look at, Bill, on your model so baby that should be a material down shift because we have to take inventory back in Canada than we can turn around and sold it back but that won't happen until Q1. So it's sort of a timing-re
componenttext: I think it's the right thing to look at, Bill, on your model so baby that should be a material down shift because we have to take inventory back in Canada than we can turn around and sold it back but that won't happen until Q1. So it's sort of a timing-related dynamics although baby has got tremendous momentum right now. So maybe you're right. But writing is going to go through this transition period much like Commercial Products at. So I think the right thing to think about on Writing is low single digit growth in the fourth quarter. That will be an event based kind of transition and then we're back in gears we move through Q1 and certainly, Q1 should be strong and then certainly after that and Q2 really ramps up to support Back-to-School. So yes, there some value pipeline and value in China, but we're going to really pulled the throttle back as we go through this complexity reduction period in writing. And in aggregate that gets you to about 3.5. And to be clear, the confidence is there in the $0.80, but because we are stepping up A&P so much, we have pressure release if in fact that if there's any risk on growth connected to what I've just shared with you. So 3.5 is probably the right place to be. It would be great if we delivered more, but I want it to be -- I want to be transparent that we won't press for more in the fourth quarter because we want to get 2017 up to a fast start.

componenttext: Yes, it does. Jarden comps get a lot easier here and out. You're right, there are 2 2 -- even -- Q2 will be little tougher, but Q1 to Q4 should be a nice quarter for us. I think appliances in Yankee that helps Coleman continues -- you don't get the distribution back in Coleman until 2017 so we'll continue to suffer there. And Marmot is dealing with what everybody else in the apparel is dealing with right now, which is -- it's [indiscernible] it's been a cold, wet and white last week in the Northeast, so that's good, but everybody is dealing with the same dynamics in apparel, so that's not going to flip on to a positive on us. But you maybe right, it may be that we get better momentum in appliances, and we get to a higher number than 3.5. We think that's the right place to plan it for now given what I shared with you on Baby and Writing.

componenttext: I sometimes discount that, but we're changing everything basically. But I'm convinced that people lead to change really well just found set of changes. componenttext: Okay. And then what's driving the growth in your appliance business? Because we get the Walmart scanner data effectively, which I guess pick up more should pick up most of the brands in Walmart. So where is all that great growth coming from?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have phenomenal growth in Latin America right now on the Oster brand and Sunbeam is growing in [indiscernible] and may have been measuring. Sometimes, when we launch a new SKUs, the syndicated guys don't pick it up because we're not using Nielsen,
componenttext: Yes, we have phenomenal growth in Latin America right now on the Oster brand and Sunbeam is growing in [indiscernible] and may have been measuring. Sometimes, when we launch a new SKUs, the syndicated guys don't pick it up because we're not using Nielsen, we're using IRI. But their growth is in slow cooking in U.S. and in Paint care, which is heated pants on and Sunbeam and tremendous growth on Oster in Latin America. And so that's been a sustained story. Part of that is pricing driven in Latin America against transaction ForEx issues, but good momentum in FoodSaver, of course, which has been double-digit growth since I've been looking at it back in October of 2015 and with the launch of the new item on FoodSaver which we call FoodSaver Flow within the company, which is a whole new system that should continue right through Q4.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to touch back on eCommerce. How does the eCommerce Division works with the 2 operating model? Like where does the decision-making lie? Does the eCommerce team look at the entire portfolio terms of innovation and products and decide what to market t
componenttext: I want to touch back on eCommerce. How does the eCommerce Division works with the 2 operating model? Like where does the decision-making lie? Does the eCommerce team look at the entire portfolio terms of innovation and products and decide what to market to various brick and mortar.com or online.com, or is it more of a team effort between both operating models and eCommerce division?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think [indiscernible] will be driven by the brand but choices about what to sell, where and how to sell it will be led by the eCommerce Division, and they will be empowered to make that choice, they will be fully resourced with the standalone P&L and wi
componenttext: I think [indiscernible] will be driven by the brand but choices about what to sell, where and how to sell it will be led by the eCommerce Division, and they will be empowered to make that choice, they will be fully resourced with the standalone P&L and will drive the growth agenda for the company, leveraging digital assets that are created by the brand's team. The points of connection to the operating divisions will come through pricing strategy and pricing execution. But obviously, you'll channel conflict dynamics that can arise with this model, so that's where the point of connectedness needs to happen is what we would call trade marketing or business development where those conversations really need to be very, very clear such that we don't get into pricing dislocating dynamics between the bricks-and-mortar.com and the bricks-and-mortar or the pure-play.com and the bricks-and-mortar. So that's where the complexity is. I don't believe in shared accountability on things like there's nothing ever gets done. It's like it's begging for resources. We're going to structure this team which will be fully resourced with -- cross functional resources will have their own P&L, will have their own budgets, they'll have their own set of targets to deliver. The sales relationships will be connected to the division associated with the.com work and all of the direct the consumer.com work will connect through the P&L. Now, of course, we're going to have [indiscernible] P&Ls in the division so the divisions gets the benefit of eCommerce as well. And when we report externally, you won't see us reporting in eCommerce Division, you'll see us as reporting category-based models that likely ladders up to something more strategic than what I'm describing -- what we described today. But that's how it will work. In the front of the complexity will be around pricing and pricing strategy across all channels.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it, that's helpful. And I know this is a long way away, but as you think longer term about for the divestiture, is it fair to assume that potential exit could come from both the develop for growth and deliver entrepreneurially divisions [indis
componenttext: Got it, got it, that's helpful. And I know this is a long way away, but as you think longer term about for the divestiture, is it fair to assume that potential exit could come from both the develop for growth and deliver entrepreneurially divisions [indiscernible]

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to stick on portfolio, but I think our strategy will drive those choices. So as we continue to build our platforms out, we will learn more. But I don't think our focus will be as we get to this first $1.5 billion, I think we're going to be
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to stick on portfolio, but I think our strategy will drive those choices. So as we continue to build our platforms out, we will learn more. But I don't think our focus will be as we get to this first $1.5 billion, I think we're going to be looking to rebuild our focus within the core and grow and delivering get back to the glide path that we originally described, and I'm kind of hopeful we get beyond that glide path with some of the deals that we can potentially do in our core categories. So I won't be anxious to reset more, but that's not to say we wont. We might at some point in the future if we think that a business might be better value as part of somebody else's architecture. The things we're keeping is the things we want to keep, and we believe in. But we'll learn more as we go. And our focus is going to be growth after we get through this period of resetting the portfolio, both organic and externally developed and delivered growth.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: I'll be very brief here in terms of one question. I think looking at next year and the drag from currencies, commodities. The currency is getting a little bit worse -- I'm sorry, it will be better commodity worse. So how do you think guys think about combined drag on earnings next year versus what you're seeing in '16?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll have more commodity inflation next year. Resin cost will be higher. Nothing like we've experienced on prior years periods, but we'll have to a little bit more pricing and we'll have to watch that very carefully. FX is actually -- we'll have mor
componenttext: Yes, we'll have more commodity inflation next year. Resin cost will be higher. Nothing like we've experienced on prior years periods, but we'll have to a little bit more pricing and we'll have to watch that very carefully. FX is actually -- we'll have more of a headwind next year potentially slightly more nothing like what we saw work in '15. It really depends on relative moves and interest rates, but we've built a modest increase in FX impact. If you look at the FX impact, the translation impact in the third quarter relative to the second quarter, we had 105 basis points of headwind in the third quarter versus 75 year-to-date, so it gotten a little bit worse. But it's kind of a massive shift.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, essentially we've would assume the market today as they are or what we're going to see into next year and as Mike said, that's net and drag on the results for next year. Principally, where we saw the sharpest move is in the pound recently, and that's
componenttext: Yes, essentially we've would assume the market today as they are or what we're going to see into next year and as Mike said, that's net and drag on the results for next year. Principally, where we saw the sharpest move is in the pound recently, and that's the biggest driver.

componenttext: All that gets reflected in the guidance we provided and we'll see how obviously, we don't know how this will play out. We have to adapt to it. So if we get more FX and more transaction impacts, we're going  have to price to recover.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll be very brief as well. I guess, my question is just with what we've seen in the consumer landscape over the last couple of quarters both consumer and on the commercial side. We've seen some softness. I guess, Mike, I just wanted to kind of get your o
componenttext: I'll be very brief as well. I guess, my question is just with what we've seen in the consumer landscape over the last couple of quarters both consumer and on the commercial side. We've seen some softness. I guess, Mike, I just wanted to kind of get your outlook, maybe your state of the union just on -- a more on the commercial side, so I think consumer side, you have a lot of good innovation coming through and there's a lot of investments going to. But I'm just wondering maybe about commercial side and any concerns that you have over may be the next 6 to 9 months in terms of a slowing down.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've made a move, series of moves with portfolio now that makes our company far more consumer-centric than we've historically have been. And the tools decision was sort of the last in a series of choices the decision to sell Lehigh Rope and Cordage, anot
componenttext: We've made a move, series of moves with portfolio now that makes our company far more consumer-centric than we've historically have been. And the tools decision was sort of the last in a series of choices the decision to sell Lehigh Rope and Cordage, another aspect of the business that is more cyclically oriented. So we're not as vulnerable. In the new portfolio we will not be at all as vulnerable. We'll look more like a consumer goods company that we've historically look like as a blended company. So or less cyclically exposed with the Dcor business, hardware, Tools business, Lehigh Rope, Cordage business out of the portfolio. So I'm not -- I'm actually more bullish that we'll be able to ride the macro driven waves that inevitably will be in front of us at some point in time. The other aspect of your question was what, Jason?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just in terms of the investments that you're making. And I understand obviously with all the portfolio changes so just really more focused on the commercial side, the exposure there, but we've just seen I think the backdrop both on consumer and comme
componenttext: Yes. Just in terms of the investments that you're making. And I understand obviously with all the portfolio changes so just really more focused on the commercial side, the exposure there, but we've just seen I think the backdrop both on consumer and commercial, it's been a little bit softer. And just kind of want to get your view versus maybe where it was 3, 6 months ago?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look I think it's consumer confidence certainly sort of less positive. But again, that's a measure of attitude and not necessarily behavior. So I don't over react to that. I think a lot of that has to do with all the negativity in the headlines relat
componenttext: Yes. Look I think it's consumer confidence certainly sort of less positive. But again, that's a measure of attitude and not necessarily behavior. So I don't over react to that. I think a lot of that has to do with all the negativity in the headlines related to the election in the U.S. So hopefully that gets -- we know it will get behind us by the 8th of November, thanks, goodness. So hopefully, consumer confidence whatever impact that has on confidence certainly lessons. But we don't see it in the market data. What I look to is whether this input traffic down in key retailers or whether you seeing consumption patterns change in your POS data. And I don't see a material shift usually a move in confidence as low as it's gone does eventually correlate to behavioral shifts, but we're not seeing that right now. We don't know how things will evolve obviously. As the Fed moves on interest rates low inevitably do, that could create further confidence issues, you'll never know or not. And we'll watch this very, very carefully. What I've said historically though is that ideas trap the macros that you can't really let wait for the macros to help you or if they're going to hurt you, you better figure out how you're going to compensate for that. And that would be -- that's the way we tend to look at things.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then just you brought up question, so I have counter question. In terms of pricing for next year for think about the pricing that comes through in '16, I think you mentioned was just some of the commodities I think it was on Joe's questio
componenttext: Fair enough. And then just you brought up question, so I have counter question. In terms of pricing for next year for think about the pricing that comes through in '16, I think you mentioned was just some of the commodities I think it was on Joe's question maybe there will be some pricing there, too. Can you just talk about the magnitude of maybe pricing coming through next year versus what you're seeing this year?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Jason, on that, with the slight increase we probably see in resins, coupled with what we've talked in FX, I would expect to see more pricing in next year than what we have this year. We haven't articulated the specific number on that, but you would expect to see more pricing come into play next year than we had this year.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that going to be related to -- is that going to be taken with new innovation or that is going to be price increase on existing SKUs?
componenttext: Is that going to be related to -- is that going to be taken with new innovation or that is going to be price increase on existing SKUs?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's on existing and with innovation, you price the value, so we'll price right with our new innovation once we think is a modeled into what we expected sizable businesses could be. So it should be, you'd see more on the base business for th
componenttext: Well, I think it's on existing and with innovation, you price the value, so we'll price right with our new innovation once we think is a modeled into what we expected sizable businesses could be. So it should be, you'd see more on the base business for the reasons we said on cost change and on innovation, we'll always look to price to value.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, the pricing will be focused -- we had to recover transaction ForEx, so we have to price to recover. And I think over time, we're going to figure out how to price more strategically, too, as we get the reset on, as we get better information visibili
componenttext: Jason, the pricing will be focused -- we had to recover transaction ForEx, so we have to price to recover. And I think over time, we're going to figure out how to price more strategically, too, as we get the reset on, as we get better information visibility, we'll be able to really get into more exquisite conversations with the business units around strategic pricing. And we need more price of the business. I'd like to see more pricing in our business. It's going to be a healthy part of any years algorithm. Of course, we did a very minimal, which is to cover transaction and cost net of productivity benefit. But there's a strategic lever available for us to pull that I think Ralph and I spent a lot of time together at craft, and they did a good job of this through the '90s, and we need to think about how to reapply some of these approaches and techniques to this business.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Steph Wissink with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Steph Wissink with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple quick ones for us as well.Mike, I'm wondering if you can just size up the eCommerce business today and give us some sense of the rate of growth versus what you've seen in bricks-and-mortar. And then maybe a little bit more context on the sco
componenttext: Just a couple quick ones for us as well.Mike, I'm wondering if you can just size up the eCommerce business today and give us some sense of the rate of growth versus what you've seen in bricks-and-mortar. And then maybe a little bit more context on the scope of that investments around that key initiative. And I have a derivative question just related to that commitment to eCommerce. Is there a derivative benefit beyond commercialization really around analytics and measurement specifically as you think about simplifying your SKU assortment really bringing to market what you think are going to be your strongest and best SKUs?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, excellent question. So about 11%, 12% of our revenues in eComm is eComm-based, whether it's direct-to-consumer whether that is bricks-and-mortar.com or pure play.com. So you can back it to roughly what that will be post disposals and come up with the
componenttext: Yes, excellent question. So about 11%, 12% of our revenues in eComm is eComm-based, whether it's direct-to-consumer whether that is bricks-and-mortar.com or pure play.com. So you can back it to roughly what that will be post disposals and come up with the revenue base that this growth is off of. We can't measure eComm growth everywhere in the world but where we have transaction data, and POS data, we actually break down all of our retailer trends, bricks-and-mortar and.com. So we look at every product family in the U.S. for example, by retailer in bricks-and-mortar and then.com, so we're looking at trends separately since we can get access to their data in that way. For reference, our U.S. businesses are growing double-digit, have nice double-digit growth and I won't quote a specific number in the channel, and this is after year, 2 or 3 years of that type of momentum. And so we continue to grow really nicely here with particularly big platforms existing in camping and then baby gear, rapidly growing Writing instrument business, and we expect to be able to build some big platforms around Yankee beyond their direct to consumer work that they do themselves. We've got a lot of interesting things happening here and obviously this is a global opportunity to the organization that we're building we'll have -- we'll be a global organization like all of our operating divisions. I won't quote the exact investment amount but it's sizable, the savings that we generate some of the other work that we're doing will fund the investment necessary to populate that organization. The analytics question is it actually excellent question, and it's really, really important to both us and the retailers that we're doing business with in the space because nobody's quite figure out, whether it's the pure play players or the bricks-and-mortar.com players or, in my experience, the suppliers, folks like us. Nobody's quite figured out how to create moments that matter online that are linked to the underlying consumer moments that matter. So Food Storage around holidays, Food Storage -- around Food Storage around anytime that there's leftovers, writing instruments Back-to-School, interestingly enough, the online channel loses to bricks-and-mortar Back-to-School in writing, ironically. And because the online players haven't figured in both brick-and-mortar and in.com and pure-play.com haven't yet end manufacturers haven't figured out how to get their fair share of the channel in that moment that matters. And so analytics will be really, really critical to us, sharpening the way we activate our marketing programs in these channels. And there's a lot to be learned here. So this is a big part of that organization. If you look at that team, when we expose that team to, I'm sure we will at some point, you'll see a much higher percentage of the overhead structured in this area and there are some very specific skills and techniques that they are applying to glean incest necessarily to make sure we're going to return on investment. So there's a lot to do here. I don't think anybody's got it right both on the retailers side and on the supplier side.

componenttext: Can you just briefly give some color and whether it received any -- whether Jostens received any consideration for divestiture and why that would be logical to keep in the portfolio?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We actually really like our Josten business. We like the Jostens -- there's the potential for Jostens to continue to develop. It's a very, very profitable business. It involves a lot of cash around nicely year-to-date, close to 3%. It's not in our core nu
componenttext: We actually really like our Josten business. We like the Jostens -- there's the potential for Jostens to continue to develop. It's a very, very profitable business. It involves a lot of cash around nicely year-to-date, close to 3%. It's not in our core numbers at this point. We got a whole bunch of innovation that kicks in towards the end of the fourth quarter. Now, we're really happy with the Jostens business. We don't envision taking Jostens around the world, and that's why we think of it as an entrepreneurial-led business. But we do think we can do a number of things to strengthen the value creation that's occurring there by leveraging the scale of the company. But we got to really focus team that loves what they do, and we believe they do it well.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Anyway, hey, just real quick on the cost synergies. I think you gave a total amount for 2017. Can you break that down may be between the Project Renewal savings and then the synergies for Jarden? And then also a long-distance that tax synergies it sounds like some of those are starting to kick in and is that now take center just off included in the $500 million or have those gone up?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still targeting $500 million overall. Tax synergies are included in that number, and we did, as you pointed out, we did begin to get some of the benefits that, that actually in the third quarter and close to the balance of the year and into next yea
componenttext: We're still targeting $500 million overall. Tax synergies are included in that number, and we did, as you pointed out, we did begin to get some of the benefits that, that actually in the third quarter and close to the balance of the year and into next year. As far as overall synergies go in Mike's remarks just over $300 million. It's reflected in assuming next year's guidance. And roughly about 2/3 of that is synergies and 1/3 from renewal. We're going to kind of moving forward talk about this in a more combined way and obviously, we're tracking it internally a little bit more discreetly. But I think more as a combined way we'll just facilitate overall communication. So think of it as we are right on track in both programs in aggregate $300 million. A little over that is assumed in the guidance.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember just remember when renewal ends. The cost associated with Project Renewal really wind down in 2017, but the benefits roll over to 2018. So 2017 saw another big year, good year, third of the 300, a little less than that maybe and then similar
componenttext: And remember just remember when renewal ends. The cost associated with Project Renewal really wind down in 2017, but the benefits roll over to 2018. So 2017 saw another big year, good year, third of the 300, a little less than that maybe and then similar amount in 2018, but no cost associated with that because you're getting to roll over benefit. And then we'll be talking about synergies only from that point forward.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then last 1 one on the dilution on the divestiture. Any effort to really offset there. I think you mentioned some savings offset, and I'm curious what that includes outside of interest expense. But any potential here to address the stranded ove
componenttext: Great. And then last 1 one on the dilution on the divestiture. Any effort to really offset there. I think you mentioned some savings offset, and I'm curious what that includes outside of interest expense. But any potential here to address the stranded overhead, especially on the Tools business?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well,  clearly, that's the challenge is that these businesses are run with shared services and as we own them, they covered some of that overhead, that's all reflected in the value that we receive for the business, so they are stranded overhead. We are wo
componenttext: Well,  clearly, that's the challenge is that these businesses are run with shared services and as we own them, they covered some of that overhead, that's all reflected in the value that we receive for the business, so they are stranded overhead. We are working towards minimizing those. But clearly, out of the gate, we have those overheads with us that's part of why Mike have said that in the first quarter, we're looking at some of the dilution to be 6% to 7% range, and we'll abate it overtime as we work against some of the savings that we could do to mitigate it. And then as you pointed out, we have the once we have the proceeds in hand from the divestiture, then we could proceed to do some of the deleveraging as well.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to be clear, within the -- we've said over 300 gross synergies, that covers just some small things on retained cost that we will do, but it does not include anything more material. And you should feel comfortable that obviously Ralph and I are ve
componenttext: And just to be clear, within the -- we've said over 300 gross synergies, that covers just some small things on retained cost that we will do, but it does not include anything more material. And you should feel comfortable that obviously Ralph and I are very accepting of that, that is what it is, and we think it's a prudent thing to do from a planning perspective. If we were to deliver less dilution, it would require us to deliver more gross synergies or savings from renewal. And so if you were talking to Russ Torres who is head of the synergy task team in the transformation office, he would tell you that we're all over him like a rat to get more to 300 because we obviously don't want that dilution, but it's not prudent at this point to call it and because of the scope of what we're driving already. But he's -- you can be confident that he's thinking about it. He's looking at whether there are other paths that we can mine, and we have some very specific ideas that we could go execute that eventually we will go execute. It's just a question of the capacity of the organization to do more in 2017 than it already is. But we know how we will cover this over time. The question is just about sequencing and the context of everything else.

componenttext: The after-tax proceeds will primarily be used for debt reduction. Principally, the proceeds that will fall in the U.S. especially we'll act on that will be little bit more cautious on timing and how we think about the proceeds the note also the U.S. because frankly, there we might have the ability to deploy some of the cash towards M&A outside the U.S, which is highly efficient to do that, to spend the money to get permanently reinvested. So priority one is to deleverage and using the proceeds. The majority of the money is -- will be in the U.S. so we'll have that opportunity. But it is something that obviously we're trying to balance and optimize across this digital agenda as well and hit the leverage goals.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you very much, Hanna, for orchestrating that comprehensive call and set of questions. I'd love to leave a message to my team, which is I couldn't be prouder of my team's unwavering commitment to deliver through change. This is a really, really
componenttext:
Well, thank you very much, Hanna, for orchestrating that comprehensive call and set of questions. I'd love to leave a message to my team, which is I couldn't be prouder of my team's unwavering commitment to deliver through change. This is a really, really important aspect of what we do. It's the thing that gives us permission to take on risk, it's to consistently do what we say we're going to do. I feel like the third quarter was the second Pearl on the chain in the combination of Newell Brands, and I'm confident based on the drive, determination and intensity of focus that we're going to live together a really exciting story over the next couple of years. 
Thanks, again, for all your support. To anybody that's still on the phone, thanks for all the questions. Look forward to connecting to you at our next opportunity.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Newell Brands Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. A live webcast of this call is available at newellbrands.com on the Investor Relations hom
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Newell Brands Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. A live webcast of this call is available at newellbrands.com on the Investor Relations homepage under Events & Presentations. A slide presentation is also available for download. 
I will now turn the call over to Nancy O'Donnell, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ms. O'Donnell, you may begin.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's third quarter conference call. On the call with me today are Mike Polk, Newell Brands' CEO; and Ralph Nicoletti, our CFO, who will discuss the company's financial results and management's outlook for t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to today's third quarter conference call. On the call with me today are Mike Polk, Newell Brands' CEO; and Ralph Nicoletti, our CFO, who will discuss the company's financial results and management's outlook for the full year and for 2017. 
We'll also be discussing our New Growth Game Plan in the web deck that's posted on our IR website. We provided a lot of good detailed information about the Growth Game Plan, including specifics of portfolio roles and other information that will not be covered in our prepared remarks today. So I encourage you to spend some time with that deck, I think you will find it helpful. 
Before we begin, I'd like to point out that we will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures, including, but not limited to core sales and normalized EPS. We provide a reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures with the most directly comparable financial measures determined in accordance with GAAP in today's press release and in the slide presentation on the Investor Relations section of our website at newellbrands.com. 
Let me remind you also that we will include forward-looking statements in today's discussion. Actual results could differ materially due to a number of risks and uncertainties, which are described in our press release and in the Risk Factors section of our filings with the SEC. The company undertakes no responsibility to update any forward-looking statements. 
Thank you. And now I'll turn it over to Mike.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nancy. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining the Newell Brands' third quarter earnings call. I'm pleased this morning to report a solid set of third quarter results with good progress on many fronts. Third quarter was planned as an i
componenttext:
Thank you, Nancy. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining the Newell Brands' third quarter earnings call. 
I'm pleased this morning to report a solid set of third quarter results with good progress on many fronts. Third quarter was planned as an income-driven quarter. We delivered results that were well ahead of our plan, enabled by strong cost synergies and Project Renewal savings, initial tax synergies and competitive levels of growth in the context of an intense period of organization and portfolio change. 
Our momentum businesses of Writing, Baby, Food and Appliances continue to deliver strong growth, which was partially offset by expected declines on Outdoor Solutions and Commercial Products. 
Cash flow was quite strong, enabling us to pay down over $230 million of debt or about $1.3 billion since the completion of the Jarden transaction only 26 weeks ago. 
We delivered these results while also completing a comprehensive review of the business, aligning the organization around the new strategic framework called the Growth Game Plan. The New Growth Game Plan establishes a new set of investment priorities, make sharp portfolio of choices, resets and streamlines the organization from a holding company to an operating company consolidating 32 business units to 16 divisions while simultaneously scaling our innovation, design, insight, brand development and e-commerce capabilities across much of our new portfolio with the intention to deliver steady growth acceleration with rapid earnings accretion and strong cash flow generation over the next few years. 
We've driven this new strategy into action in the third quarter, announcing a series of organization and portfolio changes. We've chosen to move decisively and with speed because we have the benefit of lessons learned from the Newell Rubbermaid transformation and confidence in our team's ability to perform while we simultaneously transform. 
Our third quarter and year-to-date results are good evidence that we can deliver while changing. And in that context, this morning, we've raised our 2016 guidance toward the high end of both guidance ranges. 
So with that as preamble, let me quickly review our performance highlights and then I'll pass the time to Ralph to dive deeper. 
The  Q3 headlines are as follows: net sales have more than doubled as a result of the Jarden transaction of $3.95 billion. Core sales grew 3%, led by strong performances in Writing, Baby, Food and Appliances. Reported EPS was $0.38 per diluted share after absorbing the negative impact of about $0.19 of onetime cost associated with the Jarden inventory step-up and about $0.08 of other onetime transaction-related costs. Normalized EPS was $0.78, an increase of over 25% versus prior year. And operating cash flow was over $511 million, an increase of over 50% versus prior year. 
Year-to-date, net sales have more than doubled to $9.13 billion as a result of the Jarden transaction. Core sales have grown 4.2%, and that growth has been broad-based with 7 and 9 segments growing in North American core growth of 5%, Latin American core growth of 8% and Europe, Middle East and Africa core growth of nearly 3%. 
Reported EPS was $0.91 per diluted share after absorbing the negative impact of about $0.78 of onetime cost associated with the Jarden inventory step-up and about $0.20 of onetime transaction-related costs. Normalized EPS was $2.08, up over 28% versus prior year. And operating cash flow was $837 million, an increase of over 190% versus prior year. 
So a good set of outcomes, and we continue to do what we say we're going to do. 
With that, I will now hand the call over to Ralph, and then I'll return to provide perspective on the balance of 2016 and our initial outlook for 2017.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. As Mike noted, our Q3 financial results were solid on a -- and on plan across all key metrics: core sales, gross and operating margin and operating cash flow. We're also on track with capturing cost savings throug
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. As Mike noted, our Q3 financial results were solid on a -- and on plan across all key metrics: core sales, gross and operating margin and operating cash flow. We're also on track with capturing cost savings through synergies and Project Renewal and on track with our deleveraging plan. 
Third quarter reported net sales were $3.95 billion, a 159% increase versus last year, which was largely attributable to the Jarden transaction. Core sales increased 3%. Recorded -- reported gross margin was 32.2% compared with 39.1% last year largely due to the Jarden transaction-related inventory step-up charges in the amount of $146 million. This completes the turn of Jarden-acquired inventory and the related step-up charges. 
Normalized gross margin was 36% compared with 39.5% last year. The decline is due to the negative mix effect from the Jarden acquisition and the deconsolidation of Venezuela, which more than offset positive impacts from synergies, productivity and pricing. 
We reported SG&A expense of $938 million or 23.7% of net sales, 190 basis point improvement versus last year despite the impacts of higher integration cost. 
Normalized SG&A expense was $817 million or 20.6% of sales, a 360 basis point improvement. Both reported a normalized improvements were driven by the mixed impact from the Jarden legacy businesses, which have historically carried a lower SG&A spend rate as well as benefits from Project Renewal savings and transaction-related synergies. 
Reported operating margin was 8.2% of sales compared with 12.2% in the prior year. This decrease was largely attributable to the inventory step-up amortization-related cost and certain other transaction-related expenses. Normalized operating margin improved 20 basis points to 15.4% of sales when compared to the prior year. 
Interest expense of $125 million rose $107 million year-over-year, reflecting the higher debt balance incurred in the financing of the Jarden and Elmer's transactions. 
Our reported tax rate was 6.8% compared with last year's reported rate of 16.1%, reflecting the effect of discrete items in the quarter. The normalized tax rate was 22.5% compared with 20% in the prior year, driven by tax synergies and discrete items in the quarter, more than offset by the mix effect of the Jarden acquisition. 
Reported EPS was $0.38 compared with $0.50 in the prior year due largely to the acquisition-related charges and expenses as well as increased interest expense and a higher share count. These transaction-related expenses were partially offset by the operating profit contribution from the Jarden and Elmer's acquisitions. 
Normalized EPS, which excludes transaction-related expenses and certain other charges, was $0.78, a 26% increase versus last year. The improvement was primarily driven by sales growth, the contribution from the Jarden and Elmer's acquisitions and savings benefits from both synergies and Project Renewal. These benefits more than offset increased shares outstanding and higher interest expense. 
Turning now to our segment results. Writing net sales increased 14.5%, slight acceleration of approximately $15 million of net sales from Q3 into Q2 to support Back-to-School merchandising. Writing core sales increased 7.7%, reflecting a strong Back-to-School season behind innovation such as Paper Mate InkJoy Gel Pens and increased advertising and promotion support. 
Net sales in Home Solutions declined 19.1% due primarily to the divestiture of the Dcor business. Core sales, which excludes the Rubbermaid Consumer Storage totes business that is held for sale, declined 0.5%, primarily attributable to the timing impact of the transition of the key distribution center in the beverage business. 
Tools net sales declined 5.7%, driven by continued challenges in Brazil and negative foreign currency, partially offset by growth in Europe. 
Commercial Products net sales declined 3.7%, primarily due to the divestiture of the Rubbermaid medical cart business, the negative impact of foreign currency and softness in the North American distribution trade channel related to ongoing plan complexity reduction activity. Core sales decreased 1.8%. 
Baby grew net sales 11.3% largely due to continued strong sales momentum in North America from Graco and Baby Jogger. Core sales, which excludes the Teutonia business that was held-for-sale, increased 10.6%. 
Turning now to legacy Jarden segments. I will refer to net and core sales as compared with pro forma results for the same period in 2015. 
Net sales in branded consumables increased 5% and core sales increased 0.6%. Waddington, which is reflected in core sales as of August 1, grew mid-single digits. Yankee Candle grew more modestly as we lapped last year's pipeline sale at Walmart. Core growth was partially offset by weak performance of the Safety & Security business outside the United States. 
Consumer Solutions net sales increased 7.9%. Core sales, which exclude the U.S. Heaters, Humidifiers and Fans business that is held for sale, increased 9.3%, driven by strong results in both North America and Latin America. 
We had good growth in Crockpot, Sunbeam and FoodSaver, fueled by innovation such as the new FoodSaver food preservation system, which launched in Q3. 
Outdoor Solutions net sales increased 12.1% largely attributable to the Jostens acquisition. Core sales, which excludes the Winter Sports business that is held for sale, declined 3.2% compared with prior year, with growth in Pure Fishing more than offset by declines in Coleman. 
Net sales in Process Solutions increased 11.4%. Core sales increased 12.4% compared with prior year due to volume growth and commodity-based pricing. 
Let's turn now to Q3 core sales by geography. North America, which represents about 80% of total sales, grew core growth by 3.1% led by strong growth in Baby and Writing. 
In EMEA, core sales grew 2.7%, reflecting continued strong growth in Yankee Candle, partially offset by weakness in Commercial Products. 
Latin America delivered strong core growth sales growth of 15.2%, driven by robust sales in Consumer Solutions and Writing. 
Asia Pacific core sales declined 8.4% due primarily to softness in our Safety & Security business [indiscernible] from that region. 
During Q3, we reported $511 million of operating cash flow compared with $340 million in the prior year. The improvement reflects contribution from Jarden, improved operating results across the portfolio and favorable working capital movements. 
We returned $92 million in dividends to shareholders. We also paid down debt by $231 million, which brings our quarter-end gross debt balance down to $12.75 billion. With the benefit of the cash proceeds from the upcoming sale of Tools, we are now projecting that we'll reach our 3 to 3.5x leverage goal ahead of plan. 
In summary, a good quarter with progress on many fronts. At this point, I'll turn the call back to Mike.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ralph. If you no doubt know, we've been hard at work laying the groundwork for accelerated performance and value creation. Creation of Newell Brands strengthens our presence in existing geographies and customers and enhances our reach to an extend
componenttext:
Thanks, Ralph. If you no doubt know, we've been hard at work laying the groundwork for accelerated performance and value creation. Creation of Newell Brands strengthens our presence in existing geographies and customers and enhances our reach to an extended international footprint and access to new channels of distribution. This new scale gives us the opportunity to make life better for hundreds of millions of consumers every day, where they live, learn, work and play. 
This New Growth Game Plan has at its core this bold ambition and vision, and a new set of investment priorities and portfolio choices that will shape our growth ambitions and resource allocation. Strategy is designed to unlock the unique opportunity that's inherent in the categories of both legacy companies. 
Across the Newell Brands portfolio, we have leading brands to compete in large growing categories that are responsive to activity. These are categories that are unconsolidated and, as a result, have a low cost of growth. These unique conditions create a unique potential for the company prepared to make the investments necessary to capture the market share consolidation opportunity. 
Over the last 5 years, we've invested to build advantaged capabilities in insight, design, innovation, brand marketing, e-commerce and collaborative selling that differentiate us versus our sub-scaled competitive set. We've reshaped the company from a holding company to an operating company, releasing costs that have been reinvested to both build these scaled competitive advantages in our core growth capabilities and to more than double the E&P investment on the legacy Newell Rubbermaid brands. 
This operating model has worked as it's evident in the company's performance. Capturing the transformative value-creation opportunity inherent in the Newell Rubbermaid combination with Jarden will be a function of our success applying this model more broadly. The New Growth Game Plan is designed to do just that, apply this proven playbook across a broader set of categories and geographies. And we're moving fast now to drive this new strategy into action. 
We've announced our intention to focus our portfolio on the categories with the greatest potential, divesting about $1.5 billion of business with a definitive agreement now reached to sell more cyclical Tools business to a strategic buyer at an attractive multiple. 
We will also divest a number of other noncore businesses, including Winter Sports, Rubbermaid Consumer Storage, U.S. Heaters, Humidifiers and Fans, Lehigh Rope and Cordage and a number of smaller brands, including Teutonia, Zoot and Squadra. The work to sell these assets has begun. And we hope to have buyers lined up for these businesses by the end of 2017. 
We've also made a new set of investment priorities, clustering the balance of our businesses against 3 discrete portfolio roles: win bigger, develop for growth and deliver entrepreneurially. These 3 roles will shape resource allocation with win bigger categories benefiting from higher advertising and promotion investment and develop for growth categories receiving a meaningful increase in insight and design investment as we work to strengthen the funnel of future growth ideas. 
Both our win bigger and develop for growth categories will leverage a delivery and development operating model like the one previously deployed on the legacy Newell Rubbermaid businesses. 
Our deliver entrepreneurially businesses will be led and resourced more autonomously with very specific business targets that ladder up to the overall company performance. 
We've also begun the comprehensive reset of the organization that flows from these priorities. We'll consolidate 32 businesses to 16 Global Divisions, with these divisions becoming the key operating nodes of the company. We will scale our U.S. selling organization, creating integrated selling teams in our top 20 retail partners that account for 50% of our U.S. revenue.  We will create global centers of expertise in key HR and finance disciplines and establish new global functions in procurement, IT and legal. We will build 2 new design hubs in Chicago and New York and increase investment in brand research, as we extend the reach of these advantage capabilities to new Jarden brands. We will create a new Global eCommerce Division that will assume accountability for delivering over $1 billion of incremental growth across the enterprise by 2020. We expect to have the U.S. organization reset by the end of the year with the rest of the world to follow sometime in 2017. 
With this scope of change, we're making very good progress on costs with tremendous opportunity still ahead. We've delivered over $100 million in incremental 2016 savings related to Project Renewal through the third quarter. And we are well on our way to deliver between $130 million and $140 million of incremental savings for the full year. The cost synergy teams are now in full flight, with excellent progress on procurement, corporate duplication and corporate functions, and now, the operating divisions. 
The decisive action to reshape the portfolio set new investment priorities and reset the organization where released -- where we'll release the accelerated savings and synergies we've committed to deliver, ensuring earnings development while simultaneously enabling investment for growth. 
Let me now turn to our 2016 outlook and our initial outlook for 2017. This morning, we increased Newell Brands' 2016 full year guidance, raising the bottom of the guidance ranges. We now expect to deliver 2016 full year core sales growth of 3.5% to 4% and full year normalized EPS of $2.85 to $2.90. We're tracking towards the high end of the new core sales guidance range and the midpoint of the new normalized EPS range. 
Our full year 2016 guidance assumes just over $210 million in incremental gross cost savings related to both Project Renewal and cost and tax synergies from the combination with Jarden. And with the benefit of tax synergies and onetime tax benefits in the third quarter, we now expect the full year tax rate to be about 27.5%. 
Our revised guidance assumes the assets held for sale are not divested until January 1, 2017, and that the current share count of just over 486 million shares remains essentially unchanged through the end of 2016. 
This morning, we've also provided our initial outlook for 2017. We expect full year core sales growth of 3% to 4% and normalized earnings per share of $2.85 to $3.05. Our 2017 guidance metrics assumes we complete the divestiture of all assets held for sale on January 1, 2017, resulted -- resulting in normalized earnings per share dilution net of interest expense benefit of about $0.20 per share. 
Our 2017 guidance assumes just over $300 million in incremental gross cost savings related to Project Renewal and the incremental cost and tax synergies related to the combination with Jarden. We will spend some of these benefits back in the business as we extend our growth capabilities to the Jarden businesses and scale our e-commerce division. We expect the 2017 share count to be about 488 million shares and the tax rate to be between 26% and 27%.
