We expect to deliver strong double-digit normalized operating income and normalized net income in 2017 despite the dilutive impact of divestitures and higher interest expense associated with the Jarden transaction. 
While we do not provide quarterly guidance, I do want to make sure you're taking the following dynamics into consideration as you think about the next 2 quarters. 
First, regarding the fourth quarter of 2016, we've taken the decision to invest significantly more A&P in Q4 than we did in Q3, with investment prioritized against new innovations like the launch of Rubbermaid Brilliance, one of our best-ever food storage line of products that provides a seal that simply will not leak. And on Yankee Candle with a significant new investment in advertising during the holidays. Given our current growth assumptions for the fourth quarter, this increased level of investment to over 6% of revenue on the legacy Newell Rubbermaid brands will likely yield fourth quarter normalized earnings per share of about $0.80, which would represent about a $0.24 increase in normalized earnings per share versus prior year or about a 43% increase. 
To be clear, we have -- if we have earnings upside to the fourth quarter, we would likely take the opportunity to make further investments for growth rather than let the benefits flow to furthering what is already very strong earnings performance. 
With regard to the first quarter of 2017, as we discussed on our second quarter earnings call, we expect normalized earnings per share dilution in the first quarter of 2017 versus 2016. The first quarter is a seasonally low earnings quarter for both legacy Jarden and Newell Rubbermaid. And earnings per share will be burdened by the significantly higher share count and interest expense related to the combination. 
Since our last call, we've announced the sale of our Tools business and plans to divest a number of other businesses. We expect a full year dilution net of interest expense benefit to be about $0.20, with that dilution skewed more to the first half of the year, driven by the phasing of mitigating actions assumed in the net impact. We expect the first quarter impact of dilution net of interest expense benefit to be about $0.06 to $0.07, assuming the transactions are completed by January 1. So I would encourage you to take this into account in your first quarter estimates. 
So in closing, we're moving now with speed and decisiveness to capture the transformative value-creation opportunity inherent in the combination of Newell Rubbermaid and Jarden. Year-to-date, we've grown core sales 4.2% and delivered normalized EPS growth of over 28% despite the potential distraction that a transaction of this size could create. 
We've reset our corporate strategy and launched the New Growth Game Plan with a clear road map that sets new investment priorities, strengthens our portfolios and reshapes the organization. These actions are in full flight, and we expect them to be largely completed before the first anniversary of the combination. 
We're simultaneously making new investments in design, insights and e-commerce. And we'll decisively move resourcing to our highest priority, win bigger and develop for growth categories as part of the 2017 plan. 
Our cost and savings programs are delivering on an -- on our -- on an accelerated timetable. We now expect to deliver over $210 million in combined growth savings in 2016 and have a line of sight to over $300 million in combined incremental gross savings and tax synergies in 2017. 
We have raised guidance for 2016 and have an ambitious plan for 2017 that will deliver strong double-digit normalized operating income and normalized net income growth despite the lost income and retained cost associated with divestitures. 
We're generating a lot of cash through the operations and by the end of 2016 now expect to a pay down about $2 billion of debt since the completion of the Jarden transaction. And with the incremental U.S.-based net proceeds from the divestitures available into early 2017, we should be in a position to accelerate debt repayment further. 
Our principles for capital allocation are clear and firm. We will invest in value-creating CapEx and restructuring. We will generate dividends in our 30% to 35% payout ratio range. We will drive our leverage ratio to the targeted 3 to 3.5x range with both gross debt reduction and EBITDA development. And over time, our cash generative business will create many options to complement our organic agenda with external development of our core categories. 
With the choice to restructure our portfolio and the generation of substantial net proceeds from those divestitures, we can now envision paths to accelerate achievement of our leverage ratio targets while simultaneously pursuing the external development of our anchored categories through bolt-on M&A in the core. 
This is an exciting time to be part of Newell Brands. I want to thank our people for their hard work and unwavering focus on delivery. Execution is an everyday thing, and I'm very proud of our team's determination and drive for results, particularly in the midst of tremendous change. Together, we're building a larger, stronger, fast growing and more profitable company. Our confidence is high because our team has done this kind of work before. We're incredibly well positioned to grow our brands, are energized by the opportunity to create a lot of value for our shareholders and are driven by the prospects of building one of the leading consumer goods companies in the world, a company that helps make life better for hundreds of millions of consumers every day where they live, learn, work and play. That is both the promise and the potential of Newell Brands. 
With that, I'd like to pass the call back to Hannah, who'll open the line for questions.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Lauren Lieberman with Barclays.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So many questions, I don't know where to start. Let me first ask the modeling question, Ralph. If we're assuming or you're assuming that all the divestitures close on January 1, but that's probably not actually the way it will play out, unless I'm missing
componenttext: So many questions, I don't know where to start. Let me first ask the modeling question, Ralph. If we're assuming or you're assuming that all the divestitures close on January 1, but that's probably not actually the way it will play out, unless I'm missing something, how do we possibly model this? We don't really have those pieces. So I mean. is it best to just kind of plug for it to get to the EPS that you're talking about?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Lauren, I think your point is right because we can't predict the exact date of when these transactions will close, so we thought it'll be helpful for you to have an anchor point with an assumption. And that assumption would be that it all gets transa
componenttext: Yes, Lauren, I think your point is right because we can't predict the exact date of when these transactions will close, so we thought it'll be helpful for you to have an anchor point with an assumption. And that assumption would be that it all gets transacted at the beginning of the year. And if that occurred, it's -- it would equate -- on all the divestitures, it would equate to about $0.20 of dilution. So from that, as the actual time tables unfold, as we move through the year, we'll share that with you. You'll see that and we'll adjust accordingly. I'd say also that, which -- and Mike kind of alluded to in his remarks, the slope of the curve of the dilution is something you also have to be mindful of because while the dilution is assumed to be the full year starting on January 1, some of the savings offsets that we're going to be pursuing will take a little bit more time to evolve throughout the year. So the curve is a little bit skewed to the first and second quarters of the year. Mike said $0.06 to $0.07 in the first quarter. That's you should be factoring in and if the timing of the closing suggest, obviously that we'll get -- we'll give you some guidance on that as it materializes.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lauren, so it's an excellent question. And yes, we could have played at 1 of 2 ways. We could have held on guidance until we had more clarity or we could give you a starting point. We chose to give you a starting point. Well, we have a couple of opportuni
componenttext: Lauren, so it's an excellent question. And yes, we could have played at 1 of 2 ways. We could have held on guidance until we had more clarity or we could give you a starting point. We chose to give you a starting point. Well, we have a couple of opportunities to communicate, at least one opportunity to communicate publicly between now and earnings at the end of January. And we'll take the opportunity to provide clarity at that moment, any incremental clarity that we can provide with those -- as those opportunities present themselves. We could have played at 1 or 2 ways. We chose to play it this way, so that you could start thinking about this. There's probably very few companies there as complex to model right now as us given the assets going out, given the changes we're making in the business and given some of the unique dynamics underway in some of our categories. Obviously, some businesses that have -- they're performing well. Other businesses are dealing with consequences of things -- of outcomes that happened earlier in the year or external events like weather. And we'll try to help provide as much visibility to all of that as possible without getting stuck in sort of too many inside baseball type of discussions.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think -- I mean, the decision to share as much early is great. I just -- my head is twirling a little on how to make it fit into Excel. Let me ask you just more of a revenue question. The Safety & Security business, that international business tha
componenttext: Okay. I think -- I mean, the decision to share as much early is great. I just -- my head is twirling a little on how to make it fit into Excel. Let me ask you just more of a revenue question. The Safety & Security business, that international business that you talked about being weak, it's actually one I'm not familiar with in my coverage of Jarden. So if you could tell me little bit about what that business is, what the outlook for it is. Is that possibly a piece of [indiscernible] in the slide deck. There's still going to be exit the small number, but there's still exits on our divestitures. So any color on both of those piece would be great.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First Alert has a relationship with a publicly traded company in the U.K. called Sprue. And we source and provide one of the most important ingredients that they use in the -- and we use together in the creation of First Alert finished product for Europe
componenttext: First Alert has a relationship with a publicly traded company in the U.K. called Sprue. And we source and provide one of the most important ingredients that they use in the -- and we use together in the creation of First Alert finished product for Europe out of Asia. And you've got -- if you look at the complexion of our results, you see good growth in North America, good growth in Latin America, good growth in Europe. And then you see down elevator in Asia. The down elevator in Asia relates largely to this business. And this has been an issue that, that Jarden business has been dealing with all year long related to an assumption that was made in 2015 about regulatory shift that would require all households in -- all new households in France and Germany to have carbon monoxide protection and carbon -- and smoke alarms. And that legislation has been not fully enforced in 2016. But there was a lot of growth in 2015 on that business related to the impending change. And so the business -- the Branded Consumables business, the First Alert business has actually had a great year in the U.S. But it's been offset, in many ways, by significant year-over-year down elevators. And if we don't -- the First Alert business for the full year, the impact would have been about $50 million in the full year to core sales. And so this was not -- this is not a surprise. This is a known issue and we've been dealing with it all along. But that's what that comment relates to. It relates to the fact that we're working through this 2015 big bubble positive event in 2016. And by the end of the year, we've lapped all of that noise. And we're back to steady-state, and we can get on with growing our business. If you want to read what Sprue has to say about this, you can read their public comments given that they're publicly traded company on the AIM Exchange. So that's what that specifically relates to. And we don't typically get into all that level of detail, but I'm happy to if it's helpful to help explain some of the dynamics because to your point earlier, there is a lot going on in the moving parts of the business. And we're -- we've made the choice to move with speed to resolve these issues or to take advantage of opportunities. Our choice to see the complexity reduction work through on Rubbermaid Commercial Products and absorb the core sales hit associated with that is grounded in the believe that, that's the right thing to set up the future. If you look at the operating income margin in Commercial Products in the third quarter, you see a 250 basis point improvement in margin. Well, guess what, it's connected to some of those choices. And so we're going to see these choices through, irrespective of the consequences to our headline numbers because of the right thing to do to set up the future and to set up '17. And we'll take the bumps. We'll deal with the potholes and the bumps in the road with you guys and help explain it to you. But we're moving forward in a single-mindedly focused way to set up '17 in the new context of the New Growth Game Plan. And that's why I guided 2, 3 down to the low end of the range. That's why I said a month or so back that Q4 would be in the middle of the range. We're going to take the choices, we believe, are right for the future of the business and see this through irrespective of potentially having more income-driven quarters like we had in Q3 and like we might have in Q4 versus your expectation of us to get to the high end of our core sales growth ranges. And so a lot of that's happening. There's a lot of moving parts underneath the surface. Again, happy to explain it, but not going to hesitate to move forward and set up the future.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Nik Modi with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Nik Modi with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick questions for me. The -- Mike, maybe you can provide some kind of State of the Union on category growth. It looks like, generally speaking, looking at all the other consumer companies out there and the retailers, things seem to have slowed do
componenttext: Just 2 quick questions for me. The -- Mike, maybe you can provide some kind of State of the Union on category growth. It looks like, generally speaking, looking at all the other consumer companies out there and the retailers, things seem to have slowed down sequentially. So I just want to get your thoughts on that. And then just coupled with that, if you can give us some progress on market share development across some of the key businesses. And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. So we don't see major shifts in category growth right now in the markets that we can measure. So for example in the third quarter, Writing had -- as a category, is a market had a very good growth. We had tremendous growth from a POS standpoint.
componenttext: Yes, yes. So we don't see major shifts in category growth right now in the markets that we can measure. So for example in the third quarter, Writing had -- as a category, is a market had a very good growth. We had tremendous growth from a POS standpoint. And if you adjust our 7.6% growth for the $15 million, we end up near double-digit type of growth on a revenue -- on a core sales basis as well. We've increased market share in the U.S. where we can -- we have good measurements by over 100 basis points in the third quarter on our Writing business connected to an excellent story around Back-to-School. And so we've come through that period with the right replenishment orders. And we actually come into our lower seasonality period now on Writing with the opportunity to kind of reset and set up momentum for the future. And so we felt great about that. Baby, obviously, we're consolidating market share. We're growing unbelievably well in baby gear, largely U.S.-driven related to innovation. You know that we launched the 4ever car seat in 2015. That's now $100 million item for us within the baby gear business, which is, by far, our biggest innovation ever. And we've now followed that up with the Extend2Fit car seat on Graco, which allows your child to sit rear facing longer, but comfortably because of the extension that we've built into the car seat, which is, as you know, the safest way to ride as a small child. And so these innovations are driving really good growth. And in baby gear, we've consolidated share, again, as best we can measure it. But with over 10% growth and with the kind of POS numbers we see through our transactional database, very good progress. On Yankee Candle, continue to see very good POS momentum. I know there's some syndicated data out there that would suggest there's some challenges in that category. That's just not the way we see it. And while I can't disclose the specific numbers to you because these are retailer -- this is retailer data that we get every week, we have very nice growth going on from POS perspective on Yankee. The numbers on Yankee were more modest growth in Q3, but that's related to lapping the pipeline on Walmart last year and actually, the subsequent loss distribution at Target that creates an apples-and-oranges comparison in Q3 as well. Now we're back talking with all of our retailers about extending the presence of the Yankee brand. But Yankees' underlying performance was quite good, great growth in Europe, double-digit growth in Europe. So again, one of these inside baseball underlying dynamics that we had to deal with in Q3, but the good fundamental momentum. Coleman continues to be a challenge. We're not winning share there. We're going to lose share there this year related to distribution. Marmot dealing with the macro issues associated with both apparel and the consequences of last year's warm weather. Appliances, building share. These are, I'd say, evolve the Jarden businesses, the one to kind of highlight is the tremendous momentum on JCS, Jarden Consumer Solutions. It's been a full year of great growth and that's going to -- should continue into the fourth quarter with a whole series of new appliance launches. So we're, in general, in a very good shape. We've get these dynamics like Sprue, which is the distributor issue we talked about in Europe related to First Alert. You've got Yankee having to lap year-ago dynamics and having the consequences of the subsequent loss distribution at Target. You've got complexity reduction choices that we've made on Rubbermaid Commercial Products that we're going to see through because they're the right things for the long term. And you've got the loss distribution on Coleman. So these things -- you've got a mixed picture. Food storage, great growth, great market share growth, over 100 basis points of market share growth in Food Storage related to the early launch of -- early '16 launch of FreshWorks. And now, we're really excited about what happens with Brilliance. So at the beginning of the year, I told you guys that we were -- this was the renaissance year for Rubbermaid. It's really coming to life, obviously, through Food Storage. Beverages, fine growth on POS. But as a result of the pull forward into June related to the distribution transformation -- distribution center transition in July, not as great top line in the quarter, but very good underlying momentum. And we're going to have a really strong Q4. So I think we're exactly where we thought we were going to be. We're going to see these things through. The next business that's on the hit parade from a complexity reduction standpoint is our Writing business. And so we've talked about this all along, about going after 50 SKUs -- 50% of the SKUs and about 50% of the product line. We're in the midst of that. And we're going to drive that all the way home through the first quarter and into -- through the fourth quarter and into the first quarter. This set up next year's Back-to-School with the benefits of margin development becoming available through that window. So we're going to see these things all the way through because they're critical to renewal delivery and Project Renewal savings delivery. And they're the right things to do for the business to give us the affordability in the P&L to drive growth aggressively going forward.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, Mike. And just on the Jarden innovation pipeline, I mean, obviously, a lot of renewal growth acceleration over the last 2 years or so has really been from innovation that you guys started to fund several years ago.
componenttext: Great, Mike. And just on the Jarden innovation pipeline, I mean, obviously, a lot of renewal growth acceleration over the last 2 years or so has really been from innovation that you guys started to fund several years ago.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you were to rate the Jarden innovation pipeline today on a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being the worst, 10 being the best, how would you benchmark it right now? And what would you characterize that Newell pipeline just to kind of give a compare and contrast?
componenttext: If you were to rate the Jarden innovation pipeline today on a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being the worst, 10 being the best, how would you benchmark it right now? And what would you characterize that Newell pipeline just to kind of give a compare and contrast?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to all of my Jarden friends on the phone listening, I'm not going to rate -- I'm not going to do the Russian judge just for you [indiscernible]. But I will tell you that I'm really pleased and impressed with the Appliance business, and we've got good t
componenttext: So to all of my Jarden friends on the phone listening, I'm not going to rate -- I'm not going to do the Russian judge just for you [indiscernible]. But I will tell you that I'm really pleased and impressed with the Appliance business, and we've got good things going on there. I do think we -- as we build out these new design hubs that I just described in the prepared remarks, that we can do some things to even make that funnel stronger relating to fit, form and finish the design aspects of the product. So I think there's some things we can do there to strengthen the funnel. But I do think there's some interesting ideas coming through the funnel out of the JCS. I think there's good innovation in a lot of places. But the thing that I would say is that this -- innovation is not art. It's science. And the discipline of innovation development is what we built a capability in. And this is where we can bring know-how to some of our Jarden businesses. And that should increase the probability of success and increase the size of some of these projects, the incrementality of some of these projects. And so you're right. There is a lead-lag kind of effect on when that work will yield. As you -- if you put through the web deck that you put out there, you see -- you'll see how we categorize different categories with respect to portfolio roles. And for the businesses that are in the develop for growth category or win bigger, we will be able to shape and sharpen some of the work that's going on there with added resources that will be co-located with those teams. But I don't think the impact of those actions really yields growth in '17. I think that begins the yield growth in '18. In 2017, we want to continue to bring the ideas that are in the funnel to market. And we want to create broader commercial success. An example of that is on Coleman. We've gone back in to a number of customers and we've gotten the distribution that we lost back for 2017. That's a commercial success from my perspective. We're pushing now on Yankee Candle to broaden the wholesale distribution footprint. I'd love to find a way back into some of the customers where we've lost presence in 2015 as a result of some of the choices we've made. And we're going to go get that done. We're in the fourth quarter on baby gear. In Canada, we will restructure of our selling systems. We're a distributed business in Canada. We're going to go direct selling business in Canada. We'll take the hit on baby growth rates in Q4 to take the inventory out of the distributor. But then we'll get this big benefit in '17 connected to building out a direct selling capability on baby gear in Canada, which will give us tremendous growth opportunity. So as I've said, whether it's Writing complexity and accepting the fact that our growth rates for the next couple of quarters will contract or whether it's baby transition in Canada from a distributor to a direct selling sales force or whether it's regaining the lost distribution on Coleman or pressing for broader distribution on Yankee in the U.S. markets, these things are as valuable as innovation-led growth. It's just commercial-led growth. And so we're -- '17 will be more commercially and execution-led for the Jarden businesses. And we'll continue the momentum on a balance of innovation and commercial-led growth on the legacy Newell businesses. But as you -- as we talk about these -- our agenda going forward, you're going to hear less Newell Rubbermaid language. You're going to hear less Jarden language. You're going to hear about our brands and about the 16 divisions we've created. And this commitment to really make life better to consumers, hundreds and millions of consumer everyday where they live, learn, work and play. And that's a powerful framework for the new company going forward. And that's how we'll map our businesses and that's how we'll begin to talk about our businesses with you.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bill Chappell with SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bill Chappell with SunTrust.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, just quickly on the M&A standpoint. Ralph, if the -- if all the deals are postponed past January 1, is it more or less dilutive than the $0.20 kind of outlook?
componenttext: First, just quickly on the M&A standpoint. Ralph, if the -- if all the deals are postponed past January 1, is it more or less dilutive than the $0.20 kind of outlook?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If they get diluted, I mean, depending on the mix of them, let's take Tools and then I'll kind of do with everything else. Tools would be less dilutive if the closing goes past January 1. I think the one that's a little trickier to model is skis beca
componenttext: Yes. If they get diluted, I mean, depending on the mix of them, let's take Tools and then I'll kind of do with everything else. Tools would be less dilutive if the closing goes past January 1. I think the one that's a little trickier to model is skis because of the slope of the way their earnings flow. In the first half of the year, on the -- on that business, we lose money. And then the back half of the year is where the profits come in. So obviously, from an M&A standpoint, all that is equalizing the value. But in terms of the pacing and the dilution, we actually will get hurt a little bit ironically if it went early in the year. And then obviously, towards the end of the year, we'd be picking up the profit. So that's the one that's a little tricky in this.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think just jumping on skis. I think it will be tough for us to close that deal by the end of the year. So we're going to -- we'll probably have to deal with the loss in Q1 that's baked into our -- into the Jarden base that happens every Q1 associat
componenttext: Yes, I think just jumping on skis. I think it will be tough for us to close that deal by the end of the year. So we're going to -- we'll probably have to deal with the loss in Q1 that's baked into our -- into the Jarden base that happens every Q1 associated with the ski business. But I think it' be tough to get it done by the end of the year. I'm sort of hopeful on Tools, although if Tools were to take longer, that's actually a positive. But I think it's best for the Tools business, for the tools team and for us to get the net proceeds in hand, so that we can work on the debt and the leverage ratio more aggressively. Because if we do that, if we get that -- if we get the proceeds in hand early, pay down the debt more aggressively, we find ourselves in a position having reset the organization to potentially get back into bolt-on M&A in the core complementing our organic agenda. And we think we'll have the capacity to do that, organizational capacity to do that type of thing because of the experience and leadership team and the speed with which we're moving through Q3 and Q4. So I do think Q3 and Q4 are set-up quarters for '17, and we're going to be uncompromising and finishing things we've started or getting the bad cholesterol out of the system in '16, so that we have a clean comparator. But you're right. Certain businesses lose money in certain quarters and make money in others. Ski happens to be a one that -- the perfect scenario on skis is to sell it by the end of the year. But we focused on getting Tools done first. We're in the midst of ramping on skis. And there's a lot of interest. So I'm hopeful we get a good value, we get -- we set these businesses up for success in the context of their new owner. But there are those dynamics, again, inside baseball dynamics of timing and impact on dilution and modeling that we'll do our best to help you with this as we get more clarity.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one question on just kind core sales outlook. I mean, I know there are a lot of moving parts, but just trying to look at -- you maintained kind of the 3% to 4% next year, but you're taking out Tools, which is flat at best right now and Wint
componenttext: Okay. And then one question on just kind core sales outlook. I mean, I know there are a lot of moving parts, but just trying to look at -- you maintained kind of the 3% to 4% next year, but you're taking out Tools, which is flat at best right now and Winter Sports, which are probably the same. I've got to think that as at least 100 basis points to kind of your growth algorithm. And so -- and it -- and that's certainly below what kind of core renewal has been growing over the past 3, 4 years or so. Do you still look at next year as a transition year as we take some of the slower-growing businesses out? Or are you just trying to be conservative as we're still in 2016?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's a lot of uncertainties, so we're being prudent. But there's also a reality probably to the first half of the year. Remember, we're going -- we're going to go through -- we have already redesigned the organization. And we're repopulating the org
componenttext: So there's a lot of uncertainties, so we're being prudent. But there's also a reality probably to the first half of the year. Remember, we're going -- we're going to go through -- we have already redesigned the organization. And we're repopulating the organization in the fourth quarter in the U.S. We'll have touched over 10,000 jobs in the U.S. between Q3 and Q4. Obviously, not -- the people aren't leaving, but they're moving into different roles and different configuration. And we're working as fast as I've ever worked in my career to get the organization reset. That organization will come up to speed and get into a rhythm of working in the first quarter that has a natural sort of startup curve to it. So I do think that the first half of 2017 is a transition half. But I think you're right. I think we'll get through this very, very quickly. And we'll get into a rhythm of working. And because the cultures are more similar than different, we'll -- I think we'll get through that transition period really well. But I do think that you have to accept that when you're making that kind of broad change, that there is some distraction potential in the business. And there's always execution risk connected to that, which is why we've guided the way we've guided. You're right, the businesses we're selling have lower aggregated growth rates than the total company, so we should get a positive mix effect in core on growth. And we will get a positive mix effect when this is all said and done on margin. The issue for all of you, because this -- because of the new rules that don't allow us to do [indiscernible] treatment on these things is that you're going to be comparing -- you won't see that margin development benefit until really 2018 after we've lapped and gotten the full year under our belt because the history will still be in our base P&L next year. But we'll try to demonstrate that to you in the -- as best we can through active engagement. But I think it's a fair challenge for us. And I used the words in the script, that steadily accelerating growth rates. I don't pick my words really carefully. That's how you should think about the growth through 2017. And we said steadily increase -- steadily accelerating growth and rapid accretion and strong cash flow -- rapid earnings accretion and strong cash delivery. And that should tell you what we think the story is. We've guided EPS, which is complicated next year because of dilution share count and interest expense. But I also, in the script, said strong double-digit normalized operating income growth and net -- normalized net income growth, which should tell you what's going on in the underlying business. And I think if you went all the way back and rewound the tape to April and said, "What did Mike say in April?" I said year 1 accretion high single digits; year 2 accretion, mid-teens to high teens and then strong double-digit accretion year 3 and onward. Well, unfortunately, the years don't correlate to the calendar year, so you'd have to kind of peak that all together. But if you go back and look at that, it looks to me like we're well ahead of what we said we were going to do. So -- but there's so much noise in all of your models because it's so difficult for you to do what normally saying you guys need to do with accuracy given how much we disclose that we're going to have to deal with the fact that -- and Nancy will work hard with you to try to narrow the arrow band around these things. We'll have to deal with the fact that 2017 is probably another year where it isn't quite as precise as it will be once we get to apples-to-apples comparators for you.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Steve Powers with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Steve Powers with UBS.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question. Does running the 2 separate operating models that you've described today limit the synergy upside to the $500 million that you've at least talked about as potentially residing in the business? Because it seems like the magnitude of syne
componenttext: So first question. Does running the 2 separate operating models that you've described today limit the synergy upside to the $500 million that you've at least talked about as potentially residing in the business? Because it seems like the magnitude of synergies available on the entrepreneurial model businesses would be materially less than the development and delivery businesses. Does that make sense?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is a -- it's a great question. You do have a second question, too, Steve?
componenttext: Yes, this is a -- it's a great question. You do have a second question, too, Steve?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you're answering that, I do have a longer-term questions I want to follow up with. But as you're answering that, if you could just -- also just kind of help us how much of business in terms of sales and profits today is going to fall under each o
componenttext: Well, as you're answering that, I do have a longer-term questions I want to follow up with. But as you're answering that, if you could just -- also just kind of help us how much of business in terms of sales and profits today is going to fall under each operating model.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't -- we didn't disclose. I thought about putting that into the web deck. I think I'm going to hold on that. We'll -- and let us get through '17 planning, so I can provide a forward-looking view. We'll probably give you that at CAGNY, so you have
componenttext: We haven't -- we didn't disclose. I thought about putting that into the web deck. I think I'm going to hold on that. We'll -- and let us get through '17 planning, so I can provide a forward-looking view. We'll probably give you that at CAGNY, so you have a little bit more specificity. We also have to get into the reporting segments as we resolved that through the fourth quarter because we're not going to report 16 divisions, obviously. So -- but you should think about that in the context of the strategic ambition I laid out around live, learn, work, play. And there's probably maybe a fifth segment out there, who knows? But we need to work through all that over time. With respect to your question on synergies, the devil is in the details. So for example, we're going to play for synergies everywhere we can get them. So from a -- for the entrepreneurial -- to deliver entrepreneurially a positions businesses, we're going to clearly go after synergies and corporate functions. And we're going to go after synergies where we said procurements, IT, legal. And eventually, as we build out a shared services model on IT transactions, financed transactions, HR transaction, it doesn't matter whether your entrepreneurial or whether you're develop and deliver kind of the model. You're going to leverage that systems. You really don't get a choice. That's not up for discussion. It's not a vote. It's not a democracy when it comes to capturing those synergies. There's certain other synergies there going to be available for certain businesses. So a business like Pure Fishing, which is a great example, where it has a big part of its business in a channel that's specific to it, you're not going to capture synergies there. You may be able to scale Coleman selling with Pure Fishing. But for the Pure Fishing out part of the portfolio that sold through Walmart, that sales synergy is going to be captured. If you're looking at Safety & Security, which is positioned as an entrepreneurial business, the home center portion of Safety & Security is going to be sold by the Home Depot team and the Lowe's steam. You'll get that bit of synergy. And so it's not binary. There's a level of granularity to this that enables you to play for some of those route-to-market synergies and certainly, the corporate-shared services synergies across the entire enterprise. E-commerce is a division, we'll cut across the whole enterprise, irrespective of whether you're an entrepreneurial-led business or part of a development delivery model. So I don't think it's going to limit it. We still believe that -- I gave you some very specific numbers with respect to growth synergies and savings for next year and for this year and we're well on our way to delivering those numbers. And to the degree we can find more, we'll offer those out. But I think -- I'm almost certain there will be more, not necessarily next year perhaps, but not necessarily next year. But as we look forward beyond '17, to '18 and '19, I'm kind of hopeful that there are. And I'm not at all fuzzed by the 2 operating model approach. I think it's actually a positive relative to what we had on the Newell Rubbermaid side. We've learned from that experience that some those businesses would have been better managed as more autonomous businesses with very specific targets that shape the margin development of them.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And so my longer-term question, it may be a bit too early, but you mentioned April. I think back in April, you'd also described yourself kind of looking out aspirationally to 2018 with annual EBITDA of about $3.5 billion, EBITDA marg
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And so my longer-term question, it may be a bit too early, but you mentioned April. I think back in April, you'd also described yourself kind of looking out aspirationally to 2018 with annual EBITDA of about $3.5 billion, EBITDA margins 20-plus percent and cumulative operating cash flow between '16 and '18 of somewhere between $5.5 billion and $6 billion. I'm just curious just given all the evolution and strategies that occurred since then, is there a way to just revisit and reframe that in terms of what your longer-term objectives are as you stand today?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's Ralph. Those goals are still in place. I would say, with the steps we've taken thus far, particularly on the portfolio, the deleveraging will be ahead of plan within that. And that will give us, as Mike mentioned in his remarks, some flexibili
componenttext: Steve, it's Ralph. Those goals are still in place. I would say, with the steps we've taken thus far, particularly on the portfolio, the deleveraging will be ahead of plan within that. And that will give us, as Mike mentioned in his remarks, some flexibility to achieve our leverage goals and then also have the capability to bring in some kind of bolt-on M&A in our core categories. So that will change the complexion over that period of time, so we'll get the benefit on the organic side from all the things that Mike had alluded to. But I would say this sort of repositioning also strengthens us overall because we're going to be moving some categories out that, frankly, would have been more of a challenge in our minds to develop and grow within that model, and then have an opportunity to bring in some different businesses in our core categories and capabilities that we could leverage and create more. So I think now, nothing in macro sense changed with that. But if you sort of think about the pieces underlying it, the leverage program is enabled and the M&A program is enabled to complement the organic agenda.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're going to get right back on the glide path, if not ahead of it because think about this, you're divesting businesses that are noncore, that don't really play in the same spaces to balance your portfolio. They don't have route-to-market s
componenttext: Yes, I think we're going to get right back on the glide path, if not ahead of it because think about this, you're divesting businesses that are noncore, that don't really play in the same spaces to balance your portfolio. They don't have route-to-market synergies or they don't have -- they don't or can't leverage your core operating model. And so we're going to get margin development from that. We're going to get the net proceeds in from that. We'll pay down the debt. It will give us access to M&A faster. But the real story in the M&A is that we have the breadth of products and categories that we want now. The whole theory of the combination is grounded in this opportunity to consolidate the unconsolidated categories. So we compete in large growing unconsolidated categories with leading brands. And so we're going to apply the model for growth to build market share in those anchored categories. But then we're going to complement it with M&A in the core. And the M&A in the core is, by far, the most interesting value-creation path we could take because we will plug brands into existing operating units, and the best example of this is Elmer's. Within 6 months, we had plugged that brand into the Writing & Creative Expression's group and delivered $20-plus million of run rate synergies. Think about the value creation connected to that. So as we get back into bolt-on activity in the core, we will be able to bridge right back to the original glide path. And I actually think ahead of the original glide path. It may not all work out. The timing may not all work out in '17. But it -- once we get into '18 and beyond, we should be really motoring. And hopefully ahead of some -- obviously, the numbers I communicated in that $5.5 billion to $6 billion excluded any disposals, but also excluded any acquisitions. And I think we get right back to the glide path. It's just we live through this transitional window. And I think we might actually get ahead of the glide path that we originally laid out driven by synergies connected to the acquisitions.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, cool. And just -- do you expect sort of to be ready to kind of be more proactive from a bolt-on acquisition point sort of middle of next year? Is that the right way to think about it?
componenttext: Okay, cool. And just -- do you expect sort of to be ready to kind of be more proactive from a bolt-on acquisition point sort of middle of next year? Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Clearly, in '17, we'll be able to principally because of the divestitures. So the timing, not exact. But yes, and so the team should expect this to be -- should expect this to be active.
componenttext: Clearly, in '17, we'll be able to principally because of the divestitures. So the timing, not exact. But yes, and so the team should expect this to be -- should expect this to be active.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, we just need to get the transition organizationally behind us. We get the quarter under our belts operating as a new team. But of course, you can't control timing on these things. So I don't know whether it'll be first half, second half, early, lat
componenttext: Steve, we just need to get the transition organizationally behind us. We get the quarter under our belts operating as a new team. But of course, you can't control timing on these things. So I don't know whether it'll be first half, second half, early, late. We don't know. But job one is to get the transition behind us and start operating in the new context, in delivering the new context. And the M&A will present itself when it does.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kevin Grundy with Jefferies.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I wanted to come back to the topic of core sales. And I guess that would sort of informs our view with underlying trend. So you reported 3% in the quarter, and Bill Chappell touched on this sort of dynamic as well. [indiscernible] the guide was for
componenttext: Mike, I wanted to come back to the topic of core sales. And I guess that would sort of informs our view with underlying trend. So you reported 3% in the quarter, and Bill Chappell touched on this sort of dynamic as well. [indiscernible] the guide was for the lower end of 3% to 4%, but that was prior to the decision to exclude the divestitures that you announced. And I heard from that as probably on rough math, probably in the ballpark of like 50 to 100 basis points. So my sense is market expectations and dollars were closer to 4% for the quarter given that dynamic. And presumably, I guess, even probably, I suspect lower than your expectations also given this dynamic. So is that accurate, number one? And I guess, number two, if so, what sort of came in worse in the quarter than you anticipated than when you gave the guidance of lower end of 3% to 4%? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's fair question, Kevin. So the things that I'm looking at is I'm looking at the net sales numbers relative to what you guys had in your models, and we were off by a bit. And I think part of that's driven by underperformance in the held-for
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's fair question, Kevin. So the things that I'm looking at is I'm looking at the net sales numbers relative to what you guys had in your models, and we were off by a bit. And I think part of that's driven by underperformance in the held-for-sale businesses relative to what you expected. And to be fair, some of those businesses underperformed our expectations as well. If you follow the Stanley discussion when they were talking about the deal, they talked about a distribution center transition issue in Tool -- our Tools business that they were aware of, and we disclosed. And so we had -- the held-for-sale business is underperforming slightly. The balance of the business came in pretty much where we thought it was going to be. I debated back with Q2 earnings, given you guys some of these moving parts that I've now disclosed like I didn't think I would be ever talking about our Sprue relationship in the U.K. But I think it's worth talking about. You have a whole series -- and I didn't talk to you about the beverage DC transition because I didn't think it was worth talking about. But I was kind of hoping that maybe we would have gotten 20, 30, 40 basis points more, but that's $12 million in a quarter. So it's not something I spent a lot of time worrying about. But beverages, there are a whole series of onetime things that we just chose to motor right on through that the beverages DC, the Sprue event, continuing to see that the Commercial Products transition all the way through. These are choices that are the right choices for the long haul. But they compromise near-end type of delivery. And we just accepted that risk associated with the guidance. But your rough math is right, but they were just -- they were roughly the same amount of onetime negatives in the business that we're working against that -- against the number you quoted. So all of that was within our line of sight. Maybe we're hoping for a little bit better or less profound impacts there. But it's on the fringes when you think about what else we were worrying about in the quarter. We were worried about disposing $1.5 billion worth of business. We were resetting the entire organization, including the sales force, which is not a small deal to do when you're -- as U.S.-centric as we are. So our focus was on the longer time frame. And in a perfect world, we would have delivered 3.5%, 4%. But in the context of what we were doing, we wanted to see the other stuff through that could have mitigated the risk. And we chose to take a longer than 90-day view on some of those choices. Because you could easily defer the transition on beverages. You could have easily deferred some of the other choices we're making on complexity to flatter the core growth numbers. But we just didn't, in the context of the kind of profound change we're driving, just didn't want to create that complexity in the organization. So we chose to ignore it and let the numbers play the way they were going to play.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I appreciate the transparency on that, Mike. And then one more follow-up for me just as it pertains to underlying business trends. So you edged your organic sales guidance like rough math now to 3.5% to 4%.  You've done 4.2%, if I'm not mistake
componenttext: All right. I appreciate the transparency on that, Mike. And then one more follow-up for me just as it pertains to underlying business trends. So you edged your organic sales guidance like rough math now to 3.5% to 4%.  You've done 4.2%, if I'm not mistaken, year-to-date for core sales. So the rough math sort of suggest the high end, you do 3.5% core sales in 4Q where the low end would be like a sub-2 kind of number. But given the comment you just made like 3.5% probably would've been what you would have like to done, but you've made some longer-term decisions for the business, which were sensible, should we be thinking about higher end? That feels like a reasonable place to be, correct me if I'm wrong.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, here's what -- in the script, what I said was that within the core sales guidance range, we're trending towards the higher end. And so back at the Back-to-School, I guided Q3 to the low end and I even said in some of the Q&A that I'd be fine if we t
componenttext: Well, here's what -- in the script, what I said was that within the core sales guidance range, we're trending towards the higher end. And so back at the Back-to-School, I guided Q3 to the low end and I even said in some of the Q&A that I'd be fine if we trip to below. In Q4, I said midpoint of the range. And at midpoint of the range, you end up at 3.8%, 3.9% on a full year. There are things happening in the fourth quarter and I've tried to be transparent about it in some of the answers I gave earlier. We will have softer baby momentum in the fourth quarter connected to this distributor transition in Canada. We will have slower Writing growth, sort of a low end -- very low end of the range connected to the complexity reduction, a manufacturing transition and a distribution transition in the fourth quarter. And that's all driven by the choices we're making to get the complexity out of that business. This is the right time of year to do it, so that when we come up in Q1 and into Q2 ramping for Back-to-School '17, we're in full flight.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With better margins.
componenttext: With better margins.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: With better margins like we saw on the Commercial Products numbers that we recorded, 250 basis point improved margins. Now in the case of Writing, we'll likely spend that money back. But in the case of Commercial Products, we banked that. And so -- and we
componenttext: With better margins like we saw on the Commercial Products numbers that we recorded, 250 basis point improved margins. Now in the case of Writing, we'll likely spend that money back. But in the case of Commercial Products, we banked that. And so -- and we're going to have really strong Home Solutions growth in the fourth quarter connected to the recovery of beverages after the distribution center transition, related to the launch of Brilliance on Rubbermaid and related to a shift in timing on cookware out of Q3 to Q4, which, again, we don't talk about -- shouldn't talk about because it's just too much inside baseball information. But we're going to have a really strong [indiscernible] quarter in the fourth quarter. So we'll have very strong Home Solutions. Weak Writing, low end of the range of what you would be comfortable with connected to the Writing complexity work. We'll have the baby transition that will cost us of $5 million to $10 million of revenue in the fourth quarter, but set up great growth next year on baby. We'll have strong performance on Appliances. We'll have -- should have very good Yankee performance in the fourth quarter given that we're spending more. So the complexion of our growth in the fourth quarter will change versus what has been driving as up until now. But again, '16 is a reset year to be able to set up or set-up year to set up this movement forward in '17, and we're going to see all that through. I think midpoint of the range is the right place to peg yourself. And I've given very specific perspective on what I think the earnings per share will look like in the fourth quarter because we're going to spend significantly more A&P behind the growth agenda in the fourth quarter.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Dara Mohsenian with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're a few years now into higher advertising spending on the heritage Newell business. It obviously seems to have worked in terms of driving sustainably higher organic sales growth along with, I guess, the innovation you discussed earlier in Q&A. But
componenttext: So we're a few years now into higher advertising spending on the heritage Newell business. It obviously seems to have worked in terms of driving sustainably higher organic sales growth along with, I guess, the innovation you discussed earlier in Q&A. But any initial thoughts on how responsive the Jarden side of the portfolio? Might be the higher marketing spending versus heritage Newell, maybe some early reads on businesses where you boost the marketing or if haven't done that yet on the Jarden side, at least some of the analytics you've run through post deal to determine where to spend.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're going to learn, Dara, really quickly here because we're putting material money behind Yankee in the fourth quarter. We've gotten new advertising that the team has worked on together. And we're going to try to stimulate more demand around the
componenttext: Yes, so we're going to learn, Dara, really quickly here because we're putting material money behind Yankee in the fourth quarter. We've gotten new advertising that the team has worked on together. And we're going to try to stimulate more demand around the customization promise that Yankee can make through broad-based television advertising as we come through the holidays. Because of Yankee's retail footprint, we'll be able to measure that really quickly. So I'm actually excited to be able to see -- pull a lever and get a response that is tangible, hopefully. We'll learn quickly because as you know, we don't want to put money into businesses that aren't going to have that kind of responsiveness. And we haven't done that up until now. We've been quite commercial through Q2 and Q3 on Jarden investment. But the money is now being shifted over to Yankee as part of our portfolio and prioritization work. And we should learn very, very quickly fourth quarter into Q1 as to whether that worked or didn't work. And we're kind of hopeful that it will. So time will tell. It's right around the corner. We got all eyes on this stuff because obviously, we'd love to grow without having to make big investments in A&P. But we believe actually that E&P has sort of been an essential part of the algorithm for Newell Rubbermaid, and the categories look very, very similar. So we think that one of the things that the scale and the combination affords us is to be able to put this type of A&P behind some of the higher-priority businesses with the goal of trying to dwarf from a resourcing standpoint our subscale competition. And we'll learn in the fourth quarter. It's right around the corner.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on heritage Newell side, I guess, where the instruments has very strong results. Are you seeing any competitive response out there in terms of advertising or promotional spending that, as we look out to 2017, could slow the momentum?
componenttext: Okay. And then on heritage Newell side, I guess, where the instruments has very strong results. Are you seeing any competitive response out there in terms of advertising or promotional spending that, as we look out to 2017, could slow the momentum?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not right. Right now, not really. We've seen mostly commercial responses, not big investments. It's going to be very hard for subscale competition to be able to afford to put money into the brands the way we are. That's part of the path. This is why s
componenttext: No, not right. Right now, not really. We've seen mostly commercial responses, not big investments. It's going to be very hard for subscale competition to be able to afford to put money into the brands the way we are. That's part of the path. This is why scale matters in these categories. So we haven't seen material shifts in the investment profiles or material shifts in the quality of the innovations that are coming to market.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last, are there other pieces of the portfolio, either on the Jarden or Newell side, which could be a candidate for divestiture post what you've already announced? Are they sizable? Or are you pretty comfortable with the portfolio at this po
componenttext: Okay. And then last, are there other pieces of the portfolio, either on the Jarden or Newell side, which could be a candidate for divestiture post what you've already announced? Are they sizable? Or are you pretty comfortable with the portfolio at this point, obviously assuming these divestiture occur?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I never like to kind of make it black and white, then we'll never do it. But we made -- we took a big swing here with the choices we've made in August, and we're going to see all those through. There may be other assets over time that we'd swap for s
componenttext: Yes, I never like to kind of make it black and white, then we'll never do it. But we made -- we took a big swing here with the choices we've made in August, and we're going to see all those through. There may be other assets over time that we'd swap for some other items in the core. But we're not active in that regard. We got a lot on our plate right now, executing what we said we're going to do. And I think I wouldn't envision anything material happening in the -- over the next 2 or 3 quarters. And beyond that, I'd hesitate to get too specific. But we actively manage the portfolio. And we have under Rubbermaid, we'll continue to -- on the combination. Our energy now is focused on disposals. It's going to shift to bolt-on M&A and the core. There may be some other things we chose to do later on. But for now, we're really happy with what we've chosen to do. And we think it'll enable management and leadership to focus on the businesses with the greatest opportunity.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Wendy Nicholson with Citi.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on the tax rate, the 26%, 27% for fiscal 2017 thereafter, do you think the tax rate stays at that level? Or does it jump back up? And then I have a question on e-commerce.
componenttext: Just a quick question on the tax rate, the 26%, 27% for fiscal 2017 thereafter, do you think the tax rate stays at that level? Or does it jump back up? And then I have a question on e-commerce.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wendy, yes, on the tax rate for 26%, 27% for '17, what that reflects is our -- some of that tax planning work that we've started actually and sort of realized some benefit from as early as this quarter and the balance of the year. So that, we think, is su
componenttext: Wendy, yes, on the tax rate for 26%, 27% for '17, what that reflects is our -- some of that tax planning work that we've started actually and sort of realized some benefit from as early as this quarter and the balance of the year. So that, we think, is sustainable. Those are tax planning things that are structural that we're taking advantage of with the combined footprint of Jarden and Newell on a global basis. Though sustainable, there are things that we're going to be, I'll call it, tacking in terms of more tax optimization over time. And I think as we evolve the company in the M&A agenda as well, that presents additional opportunities. So I think that's the right range to model beyond. I don't see it lifting materially from '17.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I certainly don't think in '18 it will because there's going to be more tax synergies. One of the beautiful thing about this is, there are discrete items, obviously, because of, I've mentioned, discrete items in Q3. We've assumed that we're able to r
componenttext: Yes, I certainly don't think in '18 it will because there's going to be more tax synergies. One of the beautiful thing about this is, there are discrete items, obviously, because of, I've mentioned, discrete items in Q3. We've assumed that we're able to repeat some of these discrete items and there'll be different discrete items. But we'll able to cover that in the base. But the going tax benefits will -- should, as Ralph just said, increase over time. That said, if you look out a few years beyond that, there's some potential that the tax rate could drift up. But I've been saying that the whole time I've been at Newell Rubbermaid, and it hasn't actually played out that way. So I always worry about the discrete items not being able to lap them, but there always seem to be more discrete items available.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Terrific. Sounds good. Then on e-commerce being my question, I guess, 2 things sort of conceptually the idea of pulling together an e-commerce division, they're going to focus on everything from e-commerce sales to digital marketing and all that kind of s
componenttext: Terrific. Sounds good. Then on e-commerce being my question, I guess, 2 things sort of conceptually the idea of pulling together an e-commerce division, they're going to focus on everything from e-commerce sales to digital marketing and all that kind of stuff, I assume, correct me if I'm wrong. But the $1 billion of sales through e-commerce channels, how much of that do you expect will be through your own website, direct-to-consumer? Or is that all going to be through independent retail websites? And is that going to be margin accretive or dilutive to the existing margin?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so let me be clear about that. This is a commercial organization, so this is a selling and demand conversion organization. They will not be spending the vast majority of their time on digital market, that will be the brand development organization. T
componenttext: Yes, so let me be clear about that. This is a commercial organization, so this is a selling and demand conversion organization. They will not be spending the vast majority of their time on digital market, that will be the brand development organization. Those are people that'll be creating the digital assets and thinking about the digital media strategy. So the brand owners will own that work. This is a group of people that will be focused, and it will be a sizable group of people who will be focused on taking the demand created by the brand teams and converting it to purchase in these channels. And their focus is going to be largely brick-and-mortar.com and pure-play.com. We do not envision a huge movement forward on direct-to-consumer, except in the Yankee business and then selected other businesses like Marmot and potentially Coleman and Baby. But the reality is that the vast majority of that growth is going to come from bricks-and-mortar.com and pure-play.com. And so the selling aspects around Amazon as a pure play or Alibaba as a pure play, or walmart.com as a pure play, that will be led by this team. And they'll be working in partnership with the bricks-and-mortar teams to drive conversion of demand to purchase in the channel. It's going to be really, really exciting. The $1 billion of growth, I think, is conservative in terms of what's possible by 2020. But we're ramping that capability now. And the hub of that organization will be one floor below the executive team in Hoboken. So we're going to keep that team right next to us because of the importance of its delivery against our growth agenda.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the margin profile of that $1 billion of sales.
componenttext: And the margin profile of that $1 billion of sales.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually just depends on what happens going forward. Today, dot com margins are generally better than brick-and-mortar margins because you have lower selling expense connected to it. If you think most companies have about 4% selling expense and consu
componenttext: It's actually just depends on what happens going forward. Today, dot com margins are generally better than brick-and-mortar margins because you have lower selling expense connected to it. If you think most companies have about 4% selling expense and consumer good space to be able to reach brick-and-mortar, you've got far less intensity because you don't have retail selling expense, either brokered or direct retail selling expense connected to it. So it can be -- it's about parity of growth, but it's more profitable through the below-the-line aspects of it.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Bill Schmitz with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So why is the organic growth in the fourth quarter going to better? Because you -- if you look at the puts and takes, it sounds like Aerobed is going back into Walmart. Yankee is not lapping the pipeline, [indiscernible] more advertising. The pen business
componenttext: So why is the organic growth in the fourth quarter going to better? Because you -- if you look at the puts and takes, it sounds like Aerobed is going back into Walmart. Yankee is not lapping the pipeline, [indiscernible] more advertising. The pen business is shipping in China. And then you look at Jarden's comp and it goes from like a plus 6 this quarter to a plus 2, and yours is roughly the same. So am I missing something there? And I know you have a little bit of headwind on the SKU reduction on the Writing side and Baby stuff, but...

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that the thing to look at, Bill, on your model. So first of all, Baby's real, but that'll be a material's downshift because we have to take the inventory back in Canada and then we can turn around and sell it back in, but that won't happen un
componenttext: Yes, I think that the thing to look at, Bill, on your model. So first of all, Baby's real, but that'll be a material's downshift because we have to take the inventory back in Canada and then we can turn around and sell it back in, but that won't happen until Q1. So it's sort of a timing-related dynamic, although Baby's got tremendous momentum right now. So maybe you're right. But Writing is going to go through this transition period, much like Commercial Products at. So I think the right thing to think about on Writing is low single-digit growth in the fourth quarter. That will be an event based kind of transition. And then we're back in gears, we move through Q1. And certainly, Q1 should be strong and then -- particularly after that and Q2 really ramps up to support Back-to-School. So yes, there's some value in the pipeline in China, but we're going to really pull the throttle back as we go through this complexity reduction period in Writing. And in aggregate, that gets you to about 3.5%. And to be clear, the confidence is there in the $0.80. But because we are stepping up A&P so much, we have pressure release valve if in fact that -- if there's any risk on growth connected to what I've just shared with you. So 3.5% is probably the right place to be. And it would be great if we delivered more. But I'd want it to be -- I want to be transparent that we won't press for more in the fourth quarter because we want to get 2017 off to a fast start.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean -- but how much is Jarden comp? Because it goes from 6% to 2%.
componenttext: Okay. I mean -- but how much is Jarden comp? Because it goes from 6% to 2%.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. Jarden comps get a lot easier here on out. You're right. They're 2 2 -- even -- Q2 will be a little bit tougher, but Q1, Q4 should be nice quarters for us. I think Appliances and Yankee, that helps. Coleman continues as a negative. You don't
componenttext: Yes, it does. Jarden comps get a lot easier here on out. You're right. They're 2 2 -- even -- Q2 will be a little bit tougher, but Q1, Q4 should be nice quarters for us. I think Appliances and Yankee, that helps. Coleman continues as a negative. You don't get the Aerobed -- you don't get the distribution back in Coleman until 2017, so we'll continue to suffer there. And Marmot is dealing with what everybody else in the apparel is dealing with right now, which is -- I was glad to see it's been a cold, wet and white last week in the Northeast, so that's good. But they're -- everybody is dealing with the same dynamics in apparel, so that's not going to flip on to a positive on us. But you may be right. We -- maybe that we get better momentum in appliances, and we get to a higher number than 3.5%. We think that's the right place to plan it for now given what I shared with you on Baby and Writing.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Plus we're in probably the peak of some of the transition on the organization in that period of time, too.
componenttext: Plus we're in probably the peak of some of the transition on the organization in that period of time, too.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I sometimes discount that, but we're changing everything basically. But I'm convinced that people lead through change really well, [indiscernible] this profound set of changes. But that's a possible, governor to Ralph's point as well. But we'll know it so
componenttext: I sometimes discount that, but we're changing everything basically. But I'm convinced that people lead through change really well, [indiscernible] this profound set of changes. But that's a possible, governor to Ralph's point as well. But we'll know it soon enough. Whether it's been 3.5% or not, I'd be disappointed if it was worse. But again, these are reset quarters. These are income-driven quarters as we get the organization remodeled and retooled for the future.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then what's driving the growth in your Appliance business? Because we get the Walmart scanner data effectively, which, I guess, picks up most of our -- should pick up most of the brands in Walmart. So where is all that great growth coming from?
componenttext: Okay. And then what's driving the growth in your Appliance business? Because we get the Walmart scanner data effectively, which, I guess, picks up most of our -- should pick up most of the brands in Walmart. So where is all that great growth coming from?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have phenomenal growth in Latin America right now on the Oster brand and Sunbeam is growing in [indiscernible] may or may not been measuring. Sometimes, when we launch new SKUs, the syndicated guys don't pick it up because we're not using Nielsen.
componenttext: Yes, we have phenomenal growth in Latin America right now on the Oster brand and Sunbeam is growing in [indiscernible] may or may not been measuring. Sometimes, when we launch new SKUs, the syndicated guys don't pick it up because we're not using Nielsen. We're using IRI. But their growth is in slow cooking in U.S. And in paint care, which is heating pads on Sunbeam and a tremendous growth on Oster in Latin America. And so that's been a sustained story. Part of that is pricing driven in Latin America against transaction ForEx issues, but good momentum. And FoodSaver, of course, which has been double-digit growth since we've -- since I've been looking at it back in October of 2015 and with the launch of the new item on FoodSaver, which we call FoodSaver Flow within the company, which is a whole new system, that should continue right through Q4.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Olivia Tong with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Olivia Tong with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
