componenttextpreview: Just on -- why don't I touch back on e-commerce? Because how does the e-commerce division worked with the 2 operating models? Like where does the decision-making lie? Does the e-commerce team look at the entirety of portfolio in terms of the innovation an
componenttext: Just on -- why don't I touch back on e-commerce? Because how does the e-commerce division worked with the 2 operating models? Like where does the decision-making lie? Does the e-commerce team look at the entirety of portfolio in terms of the innovation and products and decide what to market to various brick-and-mortar.com or online.com? Or is it more of a team effort between both the operating models and the e-com division?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] will be driven by the brand, but choices about what to sell, where and how to sell it will be led by the e-commerce division. And they will be empowered to make that choice. They'll be fully resourced with the standalone P&L and will drive
componenttext: [indiscernible] will be driven by the brand, but choices about what to sell, where and how to sell it will be led by the e-commerce division. And they will be empowered to make that choice. They'll be fully resourced with the standalone P&L and will drive the growth agenda for the company, leveraging digital assets that are created by the brand team. The point of connection to the operating divisions will come through pricing strategy and pricing execution. So obviously, you have channel conflict dynamics that can arise with this model, so that's where the point of connectedness needs to happen. It's in what we would call trade marketing or business development where those conversations really need to be very, very clear, such that we don't get into pricing dislocating dynamics between the bricks-and-mortar.com and the bricks-and-mortar or the pure-play.com and the bricks-and-mortar. So that's where the complexity is. I don't believe in shared accountability on things like this. Nothing ever gets done. It's like -- it's begging for resources. We're going to structure this team, which will be fully resourced with cross-functional resources. They'll have their own P&L. They'll have their own budgets. They'll have their own set of targets to deliver. The sales relationships will be connected to the division associated with the dot com work and all of the direct-to-consumer.com work will connect through the P&L. Now of course, we're going to have shadow P&Ls in the division, so the divisions get the benefit of e-commerce as well. And when we report externally, you won't see us reporting an e-commerce division. You'll see us reporting category-based models that likely ladders up to something more strategic than what I'm describing -- than what we've described today. But that's how it'll work. And the point of the complexity will be around pricing and pricing strategy across all channels.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. That's helpful. And I know this is a long way away, but as you think longer term about as far as the divestiture, is it fair to assume that potential exit could come from both the develop for growth and the deliver entrepreneurially divisi
componenttext: Got it, got it. That's helpful. And I know this is a long way away, but as you think longer term about as far as the divestiture, is it fair to assume that potential exit could come from both the develop for growth and the deliver entrepreneurially divisions [indiscernible]?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to stick on portfolio. But I think our strategy will drive those choices. So as we continue to build our platforms out, we will learn more. And -- but I don't think our focus will be -- after we get through this first $1.5 billion, I think
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to stick on portfolio. But I think our strategy will drive those choices. So as we continue to build our platforms out, we will learn more. And -- but I don't think our focus will be -- after we get through this first $1.5 billion, I think we're going to be looking to rebuild our focus within the core and grow and deliver and get back to the glide path that we originally described. And I'm kind of hopeful we get beyond that glide path with some of the deals that we could potentially do in our core categories. So I won't be anxious to reset more, but that's not to say we won't. We might at some point in the future if we think that a business might be better valued as part of somebody else's architecture. The things we're keeping are the things we want to keep and we believe in. But we'll learn more as we go. And our focus is going to be growth after we get through this period of resetting the portfolio, both organic and externally developed and delivered growth.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Joe Altobello with Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Joe Altobello with Raymond James.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll be very brief here in terms of just one question. I think looking at next year and the drag from currency and commodities, you look at currency is getting a little bit worse -- I'm sorry, it look better. Commodity is getting a little bit worse. So ho
componenttext: I'll be very brief here in terms of just one question. I think looking at next year and the drag from currency and commodities, you look at currency is getting a little bit worse -- I'm sorry, it look better. Commodity is getting a little bit worse. So how are you guys thinking about the combined drag on earnings next year versus what you're seeing in '16?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll have more commodity inflation next year. Resin cost will be higher. It's nothing like what we've experienced on prior year periods. But we'll have to do a little bit more pricing. And we'll have to watch that very carefully. FX is actually -- w
componenttext: Yes, we'll have more commodity inflation next year. Resin cost will be higher. It's nothing like what we've experienced on prior year periods. But we'll have to do a little bit more pricing. And we'll have to watch that very carefully. FX is actually -- we'll have more of a headwind next year or potentially slightly more, nothing like what we saw on '14, '15. It really depends on relative moves and interest rates. But we've built a modest increase in FX impact. If you look at the FX impact, the translation impact in the third quarter relative to the second quarter, we had 105 basis points of headwind in the third quarter versus 75 year-to-date. so it's gotten a little bit worse, but it's not a massive shift.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, essentially, we've assumed the market today as they are or what we're going to see into next year. And as Mike said, that's not a drag on the results for next year. Principally, where we saw the sharpest move is in the pound recently, and tha
componenttext: Yes, I mean, essentially, we've assumed the market today as they are or what we're going to see into next year. And as Mike said, that's not a drag on the results for next year. Principally, where we saw the sharpest move is in the pound recently, and that's the biggest driver.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But all that's reflected in the guidance we provided, and we'll see how -- obviously, we don't know how this will play out and we have to adapt to it. So if we get more FX and more transaction impacts, we're going have to price to recover.
componenttext: But all that's reflected in the guidance we provided, and we'll see how -- obviously, we don't know how this will play out and we have to adapt to it. So if we get more FX and more transaction impacts, we're going have to price to recover.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: They'll both get a little worse, but nothing to get overly concerned about at this point.
componenttext: They'll both get a little worse, but nothing to get overly concerned about at this point.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jason Gere with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jason Gere with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll be very brief as well. I guess my question is just with what we've seen in the consumer landscape over the last couple of quarters, both consumer and on the commercial side. We've seen some softness. I just -- I guess, Mike, I just wanted to kind of
componenttext: I'll be very brief as well. I guess my question is just with what we've seen in the consumer landscape over the last couple of quarters, both consumer and on the commercial side. We've seen some softness. I just -- I guess, Mike, I just wanted to kind of get your outlook, maybe your state of the union just on -- maybe more on the commercial side. So I think consumer side, you have a lot of good innovation coming through and there's a lot of investments going through. But I'm just wondering maybe about the commercial side and any concerns that you have over maybe the next 6 to 9 months in terms of a slowing down.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've made a move, series of moves with portfolio now that makes our company far more consumer-centric than we historically have been. And the Tools decision was sort of the last in a series of choices. The decision to sell Lehigh Rope and Cordage, anothe
componenttext: We've made a move, series of moves with portfolio now that makes our company far more consumer-centric than we historically have been. And the Tools decision was sort of the last in a series of choices. The decision to sell Lehigh Rope and Cordage, another aspect of the business that is more cyclically oriented. So we're not as vulnerable. In the new portfolio, we will not be at all as vulnerable. We'll look more like a consumer goods company that we've historically looked like as a blended company. So far less cyclically exposed with the Dcor business, hardware business, Tools business, Lehigh Rope and Cordage business out of the portfolio. So I'm not -- I'm actually more bullish that we'll be able to ride the macro-driven waves that inevitably will be in front of us at some point in time. The other aspect of your question was what, Jason?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, just in terms of the investments that you're making. Now -- and I understand obviously with all the portfolio changes, so it was just really more focused on the commercial side, the exposure there. But we've just seen, I think, the backdrop, both
componenttext: Yes. No, just in terms of the investments that you're making. Now -- and I understand obviously with all the portfolio changes, so it was just really more focused on the commercial side, the exposure there. But we've just seen, I think, the backdrop, both on consumer and commercial. It's been a little bit softer. And just kind of want to get your view versus maybe where it was 3, 6 months ago.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- look, I think consumer confidence certainly sort of less positive. But again, that's a measure of attitude and not necessarily behavior. So I don't overreact to that. I think a lot of that has to do with all the negativity in the headlines re
componenttext: Yes, it's -- look, I think consumer confidence certainly sort of less positive. But again, that's a measure of attitude and not necessarily behavior. So I don't overreact to that. I think a lot of that has to do with all the negativity in the headlines related to the election in the U.S. So hopefully, that gets -- we know it will get behind us by the 8th of November, thank goodness. But -- so hopefully, consumer confidence, whatever impact that has on confidence, certainly are lessons. But we don't see it in the market data. Look, I'm -- what I look to is whether we're seeing foot traffic down in key retailers or whether you're seeing consumption patterns change in your POS data. And I don't see a material shift. Usually, a move in confidence as low as it's gone does eventually correlate to behavioral shifts. But we're not seeing that right now. So we don't know how things will evolve, obviously. As the Fed moves on interest rates, and they will inevitably do, that could create further confidence issues, you'll never know or not. And we'll watch this very, very carefully. What I've said historically though is that ideas tramp the macros, that you can't really wait for the macros to help you or -- and if they're going to hurt you, you better figure out how you're going to compensate for that. And that would be -- that's the way we tend to look at things.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then fair enough. And then just you brought up on question, so I have a counter question. In terms of pricing for next year, so if you think about the pricing that's comes through in '16, and I think you mentioned would just some of the commodit
componenttext: Okay. And then fair enough. And then just you brought up on question, so I have a counter question. In terms of pricing for next year, so if you think about the pricing that's comes through in '16, and I think you mentioned would just some of the commodities, I think it was on Joe's question, maybe there'll be some pricing there, too. Can you just talk about the magnitude of maybe pricing coming through next year versus what you're seeing this year?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, on that, the -- with the slight increase, we'd probably see in resins coupled with what we've talked about in FX, I would expect to see more pricing in next year than what we have this year. We haven't articulated a specific number on that. Bu
componenttext: Yes, Jason, on that, the -- with the slight increase, we'd probably see in resins coupled with what we've talked about in FX, I would expect to see more pricing in next year than what we have this year. We haven't articulated a specific number on that. But you would expect to see more pricing coming into play next year than we had this year.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that going to be related to -- is that going to be taken with new innovation? Or that is going to be price increases on existing SKUs?
componenttext: Is that going to be related to -- is that going to be taken with new innovation? Or that is going to be price increases on existing SKUs?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's on existing and with innovation, you price the value, so we'll price right with our new innovation, which we think is modeled into what the expected -- the size of those businesses could be. So it should be -- you'd see it more on the b
componenttext: Well, I think it's on existing and with innovation, you price the value, so we'll price right with our new innovation, which we think is modeled into what the expected -- the size of those businesses could be. So it should be -- you'd see it more on the base business for the reasons we said on cost change and on innovation. We'll always look to price to value.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, the pricing will be focused -- we have to recover transaction ForEx, so we have to price to recover. And I think, over time, we're going to figure out how to price more strategically, too, as we get the reset on. As we get better information v
componenttext: Yes, Jason, the pricing will be focused -- we have to recover transaction ForEx, so we have to price to recover. And I think, over time, we're going to figure out how to price more strategically, too, as we get the reset on. As we get better information visibility, we'll be able to really get into more explicit conversations with the business units around strategic pricing. And we need more price in the business. I'd like to see more pricing in our business. It's going to be a healthy part of any year's algorithm. Of course, we do the bare minimum, which is to cover transaction and cost net of productivity benefit. But there's a strategic lever available for us to pull that I think -- Ralph and I spend a lot of time together at Kraft, and they did a good job of this through the '90s. And we need to think about how to reapply some of those approaches and techniques to this business.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Steph Wissink with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Steph Wissink with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple quick ones for us as well. Mike, I'm wondering if you can just size up the e-commerce business today and give us some sense of the rate of growth versus what you've seen in bricks-and-mortar. And then maybe a little bit more context on the s
componenttext: Just a couple quick ones for us as well. Mike, I'm wondering if you can just size up the e-commerce business today and give us some sense of the rate of growth versus what you've seen in bricks-and-mortar. And then maybe a little bit more context on the scope of that investments around that key initiative. And I have a derivative question just related to that commitment to e-commerce. Is there a derivative benefit beyond commercialization really around analytics and measurement, specifically as you think about simplifying your SKU assortments, really bringing to market what you think are going to be your strongest and best SKUs?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's excellent, excellent question. So about 11%, 12% of our revenues is e-comm-based, whether it's direct-to-consumer, whether that is bricks-and-mortar.com or pure-play.com. So you can back into what roughly what that will be post disposals and com
componenttext: Yes, it's excellent, excellent question. So about 11%, 12% of our revenues is e-comm-based, whether it's direct-to-consumer, whether that is bricks-and-mortar.com or pure-play.com. So you can back into what roughly what that will be post disposals and come up with the -- a revenue base that this growth is off of. We can't measure e-comm growth everywhere in the world, but where we have transaction data, POS data, we actually break down all of our retailer trends, bricks-and-mortar and dot com. So we look at every product family in the U.S., for example, by retailer in bricks-and-mortar and then dot com, so we're looking at trends separately since we can get access to their data in that way. Our U.S -- for reference, our U.S. businesses are growing double digit, have nice double-digit growth and I won't quote a specific number in the channel. And this is after a year -- 2 or 3 years of that type of momentum. And so we continue to grow really, really nicely here with particularly, big platforms existing in camping and then baby gear, a rapidly growing Writing instrument business. And we expect to be able to build some big platforms around Yankee beyond, their direct-to-consumer work that they do themselves. We've got a lot of interesting things happening here. And obviously, this is a global opportunity to the organization that we're building. We'll have a -- we'll be a global organization like all of our operating divisions. I won't quote, Steph, the exact investment amount, but it's sizable. The savings that we generate on some of the other work that we're doing will fund the investment necessary to populate that organization. The analytics question is an actually excellent question. And it's really, really important to both us and the retailers that we're doing business with in the space because nobody's quite figured out, whether it's the pure play players or the bricks-and-mortar.com players or, in my experience, the suppliers, folks like us. Nobody's quite figured out how to create moments that matter online that are linked to the underlying consumer moments that matter. So Food Storage the around holidays, Food Storage -- around Food Storage around anytime that there's leftovers, writing instruments at Back-to-School. Interestingly enough, the online channel loses to bricks-and-mortar at Back-to-School in Writing, ironically. And because the online players haven't figured both brick-and-mortar and in dot com and pure-play.com haven't yet -- and manufacturers haven't figured out how to get their fair share of the channel in that moment that matters. And so analytics will be really, really critical to us, sharpening the way we activate our marketing programs in these channels. And there's a lot to be learned here. So this is a big part of that organization. If you look at that team -- when we expose that team to you, I'm sure we will at some point, you'll see a much higher percentage of the overhead structured in this area. And there are some very specific skills and techniques that they are applying to [indiscernible] the insights necessary to make sure we're going the return on the investment. So there's a lot to do here. I don't think anybody's got it right and neither -- both on the retailers side and on the supplier side.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Linda Bolton-Weiser with B. Riley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Linda Bolton-Weiser with B. Riley.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just briefly give some color on whether it received any -- whether Jostens received any consideration for divestiture? And why that would be -- why that's logical to keep in the portfolio?
componenttext: Can you just briefly give some color on whether it received any -- whether Jostens received any consideration for divestiture? And why that would be -- why that's logical to keep in the portfolio?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nope. We actually really like our Jostens business. We like the Jostens -- the potential for Jostens to continue to develop. It's a very, very profitable business. It involves a lot of cash around nicely year-to-date, close to 3%. It's not in our core num
componenttext: Nope. We actually really like our Jostens business. We like the Jostens -- the potential for Jostens to continue to develop. It's a very, very profitable business. It involves a lot of cash around nicely year-to-date, close to 3%. It's not in our core numbers at this point. We've got a whole bunch of innovation that kicks in towards the end of the fourth quarter. No, we're really happy with the Jostens business. We don't envision taking Jostens around the world, and that's why we think of it as an entrepreneurial-led business. But we do think we can do a number of things to strengthen the value creation that's occurring there by leveraging the scale of the company. But we got a really focused team that loves what they do, and we believe they do it well.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Joe Lachky with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Joe Lachky with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anyway, just real quick on the cost synergies. I think you gave a total amount for 2017. Can you break that down maybe between the Project Renewal savings and then the synergies for Jarden? And then also along those lines, the tax synergies, it sounds lik
componenttext: Anyway, just real quick on the cost synergies. I think you gave a total amount for 2017. Can you break that down maybe between the Project Renewal savings and then the synergies for Jarden? And then also along those lines, the tax synergies, it sounds like some of those are starting to kick in. And is that now -- or tax synergies now included in the $500 million? Or is -- have those gone up?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still targeting $500 million overall. Tax synergies are included in that number. And we did -- as you pointed out, we did begin to get some of the benefits of that actually in the third quarter and close to the balance of the year and into next year
componenttext: We're still targeting $500 million overall. Tax synergies are included in that number. And we did -- as you pointed out, we did begin to get some of the benefits of that actually in the third quarter and close to the balance of the year and into next year. As far as overall synergies go, on Mike's remarks, he had said just over $300 million is what we're -- is reflected and assuming in next year's guidance. And roughly, about 2/3 of that is synergies and 1/3 from renewal. We're going to -- kind of moving forward talk about this in a more combined way. Obviously, we're tracking it internally a little bit more discreetly. But I think, more as a combined way, we'll just facilitate overall communication. So think of it as we're right on track on both programs in aggregate $300 million. A little over that is assumed in the guidance.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember just for -- just remember when renewal ends. The cost associated with Project Renewal really wind down in 2017, but the benefits will roll over into 2018. So 2017 is another big year, good year, third of the $300 million, a little less than t
componenttext: And remember just for -- just remember when renewal ends. The cost associated with Project Renewal really wind down in 2017, but the benefits will roll over into 2018. So 2017 is another big year, good year, third of the $300 million, a little less than that maybe. And then a similar amount in 2018, but no cost associated with that because you're just getting the roll over benefit. And then we'll be talking about synergies only from that point forward.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then last one on the dilution from the divestiture. So any effort to really offset there? I think you mentioned some savings offset, and I'm curious what that includes outside of interest expense. But any potential here to address the stranded
componenttext: Great. And then last one on the dilution from the divestiture. So any effort to really offset there? I think you mentioned some savings offset, and I'm curious what that includes outside of interest expense. But any potential here to address the stranded overhead, especially on the Tools business?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, that's the challenge here is that these businesses are run with shared services. And as we own them, they covered some of that overhead. That's all reflected in the value that we receive for the business. So there are stranded overheads. We
componenttext: Well, clearly, that's the challenge here is that these businesses are run with shared services. And as we own them, they covered some of that overhead. That's all reflected in the value that we receive for the business. So there are stranded overheads. We are working towards minimizing those. But clearly, out of the gate, we have those overheads with us that's part of why Mike had said that in the first quarter, we're looking at some of the dilution to be more in the 6% to 7% range. And we'll abate it overtime as we work against some of the savings that we could do to mitigate it. And then as you pointed out, we have the -- once we have the proceeds in hand from the divestiture, then we could proceed to do some of the deleveraging as well.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to be clear, within the -- we've said over $300 million in gross synergies. That covers just some small things on retained cost that we will do. But it does not include anything more material. And you should feel comfortable that, obviously, Ralp
componenttext: And just to be clear, within the -- we've said over $300 million in gross synergies. That covers just some small things on retained cost that we will do. But it does not include anything more material. And you should feel comfortable that, obviously, Ralph and I are very accepting of that, but that is what it is. And we think it's a prudent thing to do from a planning perspective. If we were to deliver less dilution, it would require us to deliver more gross synergies or savings from renewal. And so if you were talking to Russ Torres, who's the head of the synergy task team that's in the transformation office, he would tell you that we're all over him like a wet rag to get more than $300 million because we obviously don't want that dilution. But it's not prudent at this point to call it and -- because of the scope of what we're driving already. And -- but he's -- you can be confident that he's thinking about it. He's looking at whether there are other paths that we can mine. And we have some very specific ideas that we could go execute that eventually we will go execute. It's just a question of the capacity of the organization to do more in 2017 than it already is. But we know how we will cover this over time. The question is just about sequencing in the context of everything else.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your final question comes from Rupesh Parikh with Oppenheimer.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to be really quick because most of my questions have been answered. Just on the Stanley transaction, is there any initial thoughts in terms of the after-tax proceeds associated with that transaction?
componenttext: I'm going to be really quick because most of my questions have been answered. Just on the Stanley transaction, is there any initial thoughts in terms of the after-tax proceeds associated with that transaction?

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The after-tax proceeds will primarily be used for debt reduction. Principally, the proceeds that will fall in the U.S. especially, we'll act on that. We'll be a little bit more cautious on timing and how we think about the proceeds that will remain outsid
componenttext: The after-tax proceeds will primarily be used for debt reduction. Principally, the proceeds that will fall in the U.S. especially, we'll act on that. We'll be a little bit more cautious on timing and how we think about the proceeds that will remain outside the U.S. because frankly, there, we might have the ability to deploy some of that cash towards M&A outside the U.S., which is highly efficient to do that, to spend the money to get permanently reinvested. So priority one is to deleverage in using the proceeds. the majority of the money is -- will be in the U.S., so we'll have that opportunity. But it is something that obviously, we're trying to balance and optimize across the strategic agenda as well and hit the leverage goals.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ralph, I was hoping more maybe just to get the tax impact on the transaction. Just trying to get through the -- just trying to get a sense for the after-tax proceeds.
componenttext: And Ralph, I was hoping more maybe just to get the tax impact on the transaction. Just trying to get through the -- just trying to get a sense for the after-tax proceeds.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The net, which we've disclosed already, is about -- after-tax proceeds is about $1.5 billion, just a little over $1.5 billion.
componenttext: The net, which we've disclosed already, is about -- after-tax proceeds is about $1.5 billion, just a little over $1.5 billion.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you very much, Hannah, for orchestrating that comprehensive call and set of questions. I'd love to leave with just a message to my team, which is I couldn't be prouder of my team's unwavering commitment to deliver through change. This is a rea
componenttext: Well, thank you very much, Hannah, for orchestrating that comprehensive call and set of questions. I'd love to leave with just a message to my team, which is I couldn't be prouder of my team's unwavering commitment to deliver through change. This is a really, really important aspect of what we do. It's the thing that gives us permission to take on risk, is to consistently do what we say we're going to do. I feel like the third quarter was the one -- a second pearl on the chain in the combination of Newell Brands. And I'm confident, based on the drive, determination and intensity of focus, that we're going to weave together a really exciting story over the next couple of years. Thanks, again, for all your support. To anybody that's still on the phone, thanks for all the questions. Look forward to connecting to you at our next opportunity.

headline: Newell Brands Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
